title: Menne v. Keowee Key Property Ownersâ€™ Association
description: Douglas J. Menne brought this action against Keowee Key Property Owners' Association seeking a declaration that a restrictive covenant prohibiting individual docks in his neighborhood was unenforceable due to changed conditions.  Menne appeals the trial courtâ€™s order upholding the covenant.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Douglas J. Menne, as Trustee of the First Supplemental Trust Agreement created by Douglas J. Menne dated 11/22/96 (as amended),
Appellant,
v.
Keowee Key Property Ownersâ€™ Association, Inc.,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
Â Ellis B. Drew, Jr., Master-In-Equity

Opinion No. 4100
Heard March 7, 2006 â€“ Filed April 3, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Andrea Hawkins, of Spartanburg, and Christopher M. Kelly, of Greenville, for Appellant.
James B. Richardson, Jr., of Columbia, and Samuel F. Albergotti, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Douglas Menne brought this declaratory judgment action against the Keowee Key Property Ownersâ€™ Association, Inc. seeking a determination regarding the validity of a restrictive covenant that prevents him from building an individual boat dock on his lakefront property.Â  The master in equity ruled the covenant was valid and enforceable.Â  Menne appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Keowee Key is a gated residential community on Lake Keowee.Â  The community is divided into units, with each unit further divided into multiple lots.Â  Keowee Key, a large area comprised of over 2,200 lots, covers approximately 1,600 acres.Â  Each unit contains its own distinct set of restrictive covenants that apply only to the lots within that unit.Â  
In 1985, Menneâ€™s mother purchased from the Lake Keowee Development Corporation Lot 24, a lakefront tract within Unit 20 of Keowee Key.Â  Unit 20 abuts the largest cove at Lake Keowee, informally called the Leisure Trail Cove (the â€œCoveâ€).Â Â Â  
Menneâ€™s mother purchased the property subject to a restrictive covenant that the developer recorded in Oconee County on April 19, 1985.Â  The covenant prohibits construction of individual boat docks in Unit 20 and provides in relevant part as follows:

No docks or other structures of a permanent or temporary nature shall be placed in or upon the waters or the shoreline of Lake Keowee by any individuals, partnership or corporation other than Lake Keowee Development Corporation, its successors or assigns.Â  

The developer created the Leisure Trail, a walking path along the edge of the Cove at Lake Keowee, for the enjoyment of all Unit 20 property owners, including the owners of interior lots.Â  The developer believed the natural aesthetics of the Leisure Trail would be better preserved by a few community boat docks, or â€œcluster docks,â€ rather than numerous individual boat docks.Â  The covenant maintains this appearance by preventing the construction of individual boat docks.Â  In lieu of individual docks, however, Unit 20 property owners can lease boat slips from a nearby community boat dock, the Gazebo Dock.Â  
At the time Menneâ€™s mother purchased Lot 24 in 1985, the Cove contained community docks in two locations, one consisting of 58 slips (the â€œMain Dockâ€) and another consisting of the 18-slip Gazebo Dock, for a total of 76 slips.Â  At one end of the Cove is Unit 21, which, like Unit 20, borders the Cove.Â  At the other end of the Cove formerly stood the Yacht Club.Â  It housed a restaurant and meeting area.Â  The Leisure Trail started near the Yacht Club, traversed Unit 20, and ended within Unit 21.[1]Â  From the time she bought the property, Menneâ€™s mother rented a boat slip at the Gazebo Dock.Â  
In 2000, Menne took over ownership of Lot 24 from his mother subject to the covenant.[2]Â  Menne admittedly knew when he acquired the property that the covenant prohibited Lot 24 from having an individual dock.Â  He had accompanied his mother when she purchased the property in 1985.Â  Menne also knew the covenant applied only to Unit 20 and did not apply to the other units in the Cove.Â  
In 2001, Menne contacted the Keowee Key Property Ownersâ€™ Association[3] and requested permission to build an individual boat dock on Lot 24 so he could house his three watercraft on the lake.Â  Menne explained that, although he continued to lease one boat slip at the Gazebo Dock (as his mother had done), he wished to dock more boats at Lake Keowee because, in addition to his pontoon boat, he now owned a ski boat and jet ski used by his children.Â  Menne complained about having to remove his watercraft from the lake on a daily basis.Â  He said it cut into the amount of â€œwater timeâ€ that he had on the lake.Â  He viewed the Unit 20 restriction as â€œneither fair, logical or legal.â€Â  
The Association rejected Menneâ€™s request based on the restrictive covenant in Unit 20.Â  The Association noted no private docks existed in the restricted area and it was in the process of constructing additional community boat slips.[4]Â  
Menne subsequently enlisted the help of an Ohio attorney to negotiate with the Association about building an individual dock on Lot 24.Â  Menne met with the Associationâ€™s general manager, David Coe, but the Association maintained its position that the Unit 20 covenant prevented Menne from constructing an individual boat dock on Lot 24.Â  
Menne thereafter filed this declaratory judgment action seeking a determination that the Unit-20 covenant could no longer be enforced because of a change of conditions in the area.Â  The master in equity reviewed the pleadings, stipulations, testimony, and exhibits, and walked the Leisure Trail with the consent of all parties, and concluded no radical change of conditions had occurred that would support an invalidation of the Unit 20 restrictive covenant regarding the construction of private docks.Â  The master noted the Leisure Trail had retained its aesthetic appeal despite the addition of a few community docks in the Cove.Â  Finally, the master ordered Menne to pay attorney fees and costs of $56,273.25 to the Association.Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Change of Conditions
Menne contends the master erred in failing to invalidate the restrictive covenant based on a change of conditions.Â  
Under South Carolina law, a party may bring a declaratory judgment action to invalidate a restrictive covenant based on a change of conditions.[5]Â Â Â  The party bringing the action bears the burden of proof by the preponderance of the evidence.[6]Â  
In an action for a declaratory judgment, â€œaffirmative relief may be granted against a restrictive covenant where there is such a change in the character of the neighborhood as to render the enforcement of the covenant valueless to the covenantee and oppressive and unreasonable as to the covenantor.â€[7]Â  A party seeking to annul a restrictive covenant must show the change of conditions represented so radical a change that the original purpose of the restrictive covenant can no longer be realized.[8]Â  Even if, however, a change of conditions has occurred and inflicts a hardship upon the servient estate, equity will enforce a restrictive covenant if it â€œremain[s] of substantial value.â€[9]Â  
Since Menneâ€™s mother purchased Lot 24 in 1985, the Cove has changed.Â  When she purchased Lot 24, the Cove contained 76 community boat slipsâ€”18 slips at the Gazebo Deck and 58 slips at the Main Dock.Â  In 1992, the Association built a 24-slip cluster dock off the Leisure Trail, increasing the total number of boat slips to 100.Â  Like the Gazebo Dock, this cluster dock accommodates property owners who could not build individual docks on the lake because they purchased property along the Leisure Trail.Â  This particular cluster dock was built for Unit 21 property owners.Â  In 1996, the Association added 12 slips to the Main Dock, increasing the total number of slips in the Cove to 112.Â  In 2001, the Association built a 20-slip cluster dock off the Leisure Trail called the Tall Ships Dock.Â  These additional slips, combined with the 2-slip Fordco Dock that had been in the Cove for an indeterminate number of years, brought the total number of slips near the Leisure Trail in the Cove to 134 overall.Â  
The Association also has plans for future development.Â  It has submitted an application to Duke Energy Corp. to build another cluster dock comprised of 14 slips next to the Main Dock at the beginning of the Leisure Trail.Â Â Â  
The Yacht Club was razed and replaced with a town house development called Sunrise Pointe between 2001 and 2003.Â  The developer of Sunrise Pointe built an 8-slip cluster dock and has already submitted a proposal to increase the dock to 12 slips.Â  Sunrise Pointe is not located on the Leisure Trail and is not governed by the Association, but it is within the Cove.Â  The old 2-slip Fordco Dock near the Sunrise Pointe property is slated to be removed, however.Â  
The purpose of the Unit 20 covenant is to preserve the aesthetics of the Leisure Trail that runs along the Cove and crosses Unit 20.Â  The developer believed prohibiting individual docks along the Unit 20 shoreline would best preserve the Leisure Trail.Â  By building community docks, the Leisure Trail would remain open along the Unit 20 shoreline and Unit 20 property owners would still have access to the lake.Â  To this end, the original purpose of the Unit 20 covenant can and continues to be realized.
As of this date, the Leisure Trail enjoys an open shoreline within Unit 20.Â  No individual boat docks have been added to the Unit 20 shoreline and there have been no violations of the covenant since it was recorded.Â  Although community docks have been built elsewhere in the Cove, no community docks have been added to the Unit 20 shoreline since Menneâ€™s mother purchased Lot 24.Â  Consequently, there has been little change to the aesthetics of the Leisure Trail within Unit 20, let alone a radical change warranting the invalidation of the Unit 20 covenant at issue here.Â  
Moreover, the Associationâ€™s enforcement of the Unit 20 covenant is not oppressive to Menne.Â  Because Menne currently leases two boat slips from the Association at the Gazebo Dock, two of his three watercraft are already housed on the lake.Â  Thus, even if there was a radical change of conditions within Unit 20, we do not believe the fact that Menne cannot house additional boats or other watercraft on the lake places such an exorbitant burden on him that the Unit 20 covenant should be invalidated.Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Evidence of Changes Outside the Restricted Area
Menne argues the master erred in failing to consider evidence of changed circumstances outside the restricted area.Â  
To invalidate restrictive covenants based on a change of conditions, the changed conditions must occur within the restricted area, i.e., within the area where the covenants apply.[10]Â  In Flinkingshelt v. Johnson,[11] our supreme court explained the relevant area must end somewhere and different conditions naturally will exist outside the restricted zone:

It is obvious that any restricted area, whether it be residential or industrial, must have a demarcation line; it must end somewhere.Â  Where the restricted area ends, other unrestricted development will or may foreseeably occur.Â  To hold that commercial development in an unrestricted area adjoining a restricted area would allow the lifting of the residential restrictions as to property adjoining or in the vicinity of the unrestricted area, would be to expose all restrictions to eventual invalidation.Â  It would remove the sanctity of long standing, long respected contractual agreements and place them at the whim of parties not privy to the agreements.[12]

Here, Unit 20 is considered the restricted area because the covenant at issue applies only to the lots within Unit 20 and prohibits those lot owners from building individual boat docks on their property.Â  The alleged change of conditions in the other units of the Cove is irrelevant to the determination of whether the Unit 20 covenant should be invalidated because of changed conditions.Â  
III.Â Â Â  Alleged Ambiguity of the Restrictive Covenant
Menne asserts the master erred in concluding the language of the restrictive covenant is clear and unambiguous.Â  
â€œ[W]here the language imposing restrictions upon the use of property is unambiguous, the restrictions will be enforced according to their obvious meaning.â€[13]Â  

The Unit 20 restrictive covenant provides as follows:
  
No docks or other structures of a permanent or temporary nature shall be placed in or upon the waters or the shoreline of Lake Keowee by any individuals, partnership or corporation other than Lake Keowee Development Corporation, its successors or assigns.Â  
  

The Association is the successor of the Lake Keowee Development Corporation.Â  Thus, the Association can build docks on Lake Keowee, while individual Unit 20 property owners, such as Menne, cannot.Â  We conclude the language is clear and unambiguous.Â  
IV.Â Â Â  Weight of the Testimony
Menne next contends the master erred in giving the testimony of his witness, real estate appraiser Luke Fields, less weight than the testimony of the Associationâ€™s witness, local realtor Dan Suddeth, regarding the value of Menneâ€™s lakefront property with and without a dock.Â  
â€œThe credibility of testimony is a matter for the finder of fact to judge.â€[14]Â  â€œBecause the appellate court lacks the opportunity for direct observation of the witnesses, it should accord great deference to trial court findings where matters of credibility are involved.â€[15]Â  Nothing in the record persuades us to overturn the masterâ€™s view of the evidence.Â  
Moreover, we find no error in the masterâ€™s determination that, even if Menneâ€™s lot would be worth more with an individual dock, this would not justify the invalidation of the restrictive covenant where there is no radical change in the restricted area and the covenant still retains substantial value to the residential community.Â  
V.Â  Complaints by Other Residents
Menne argues the master erred in excluding evidence of other residentsâ€™ complaints about the addition of more community docks within the Cove.Â  
The admission or exclusion of evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial court, whose ruling will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.[16]Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion that is without evidentiary support.â€[17]Â  â€œTo warrant reversal based on the admission or exclusion of evidence, the appellant must prove both the error of the ruling and the resulting prejudice . . . .â€[18]Â  
Menne offered several letters from Unit 21 property owners who objected to the addition of boat slips to the Unit 21 community dock, a dock that lies outside the restricted area.Â  Menne argued the letters showed the Association had notice of changed conditions due to continued expansion within the Cove.Â  The master excluded the letters as hearsay and irrelevant.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in this instance.Â  The only pertinent evidence of changed conditions is of those changes occurring within the restricted area, i.e., Unit 20.
VI.Â Â Â  Motion to Amend the Pleadings
Menne asserts the master erred in denying his motion to amend his pleadings to include causes of action for misrepresentation and
estoppel.  
The master denied Menneâ€™s motion under Rule 15(b), SCRCP to amend his pleadings to conform to the evidence, finding the evidence had not established either cause of action.Â  Menne argued the Association had represented Keowee Key as being a complete community that was already developed.Â  He further argued the covenant prohibited the addition of any docks, even by the Association.Â  Menneâ€™s interpretation of the covenant is clearly not supported by the evidence.Â  Moreover, because Menne admitted the Association never told him that additional community docks would not be built within Unit 20 or elsewhere in the Cove, there is no evidence establishing either misrepresentation or equitable estoppel.[19]Â Â Â  
VII.Â  Attorney Fees
Menne lastly argues the master erred in ordering him to pay $56,273.25 in attorney fees and costs to the Association.Â  
As a general rule, a party may not recover attorney fees absent a contract or statute.[20]Â  â€œWhen there is a contract, the award of attorney[] fees is left to the discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed unless an abuse of discretion is shown.â€[21]Â Â Â  
â€œThere are six factors to consider in determining an award of attorney[] fees:Â  1) nature, extent, and difficulty of the legal services rendered; 2) time and labor devoted to the case; 3) professional standing of counsel; 4) contingency of compensation; 5) fee customarily charged in the locality for similar services; and 6) beneficial results obtained.â€[22]Â  An award of attorney fees will be affirmed on appeal if there is sufficient evidentiary support in the record for each factor.[23]Â  
In this case, the â€œAmended and Restated Declaration of Protective Covenants of Keowee Keyâ€[24] authorize the Association to recover attorney fees in the event it is successful in the defense of the provisions of the Declaration.[25]Â  The master thoroughly examined the factors that determine an award of attorney fees and concluded the evidence supported an award of $56,273.25 to the Association.Â  The record fully supports the masterâ€™s findings.
AFFIRMED.Â     
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Unit 21, which was undeveloped in 1985, has restrictive covenants that are similar, but not identical, to the Unit 20 restriction.Â  Unit 21 borders and shares the Leisure Trail with Unit 20.Â  
[2]Â  Menneâ€™s mother originally held title individually and later transferred title to the property to her revocable trust.Â  Menne holds title as trustee for his revocable trust.Â  
[3]Â  The Association is the successor to Realtec, Inc., the parent corporation of the Lake Keowee Development Corporation, which had originally deeded Lot 24 to Menneâ€™s mother.Â  
[4]Â  Menne now leases two community boat slips from the Association, both of which are located at the Gazebo Dock near Menneâ€™s lot.Â  
[5]Â  Flinkingshelt v. Johnson, 258 S.C. 77, 187 S.E.2d 233 (1972); Dunlap v. Beaty, 239 S.C. 196, 122 S.E.2d 9 (1961); Martin v. Cantrell, 225 S.C. 140, 81 S.E.2d 37 (1954).
[6]Â  Martin, 225 S.C. at 144, 81 S.E.2d at 38-39.
[7]Â  Dunlap, 239 S.C. at 210, 122 S.E.2d at 15.
[8]Â  Inabinet v. Booe, 262 S.C. 81, 202 S.E.2d 643 (1974); Pitts v. Brown, 215 S.C. 122, 54 S.E.2d 538 (1949); Shipyard Property Ownersâ€™ Assâ€™n v. Mangiaracina, 307 S.C. 299, 414 S.E.2d 795 (Ct. App. 1992).
[9]Â  Circle Square Co. v. Atlantis Dev. Co., 267 S.C. 618, 630, 230 S.E.2d 704, 709 (1976).
[10]Â  Flinkingshelt, 258 S.C. at 87, 187 S.E.2d at 238; see also Inabinet, 262 S.C. at 83-84, 202 S.E.2d at 644-45; Martin, 225 S.C. at 147-48, 81 S.E.2d at 40-41.
[11]Â  258 S.C. 77, 187 S.E.2d 233.
[12]Â  Id. at 87, 187 S.E.2d at 238.Â  
[13]Â  Mangiaracina, 307 S.C. at 308, 414 S.E.2d at 801; see also Harvey v. Marsh Hawk Plantation, 310 S.C. 355, 356, 426 S.E.2d 792, 793 (1993) (â€œAn unambiguous covenant will be enforced according to its obvious meaning.â€).
[14]Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Forrester, 282 S.C. 512, 516, 320 S.E.2d 39, 42 (Ct. App. 1984).

[19]Â  See Harvey v. Strickland, 350 S.C. 303, 313, 566 S.E.2d 529, 535 (2002) (â€œA motion to amend is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court, and the party opposing the motion has the burden of establishing prejudice.â€).

title: Simmons v. Simmons
description: In this family court action, the court reversed the trial court's denial of the husband's motion for relief from judgment, finding that Social Security benefits cannot be divided in an equitable division award whether by agreement ot otherwise.
text:
Simmons v. Simmons


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Essie Simmons, Respondent,
v.
Rubin Simmons, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Paul W. Garfinkel, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4043
Submitted October 1, 2005 â€“ Filed November 14, 2005
Withdrawn, Substituted, and Refiled April 10, 2006Â Â Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Donald Jay Budman, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Paul E. Tinkler, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, A.J.: Rubin Simmons (Husband) appeals the denial of his motion for relief from judgment arguing the family court lacked subject matter jurisdiction when it entered a divorce decree effecting an equitable division of Husbandâ€™s Social Security benefits.Â  We reverse.[1]Â  
Facts
On August 24, 1990, Husband and Essie Simmons (Wife) were divorced by decree.Â  The decree adopted an agreement between the parties as to alimony, equitable division, retirement benefits, and health insurance, among other things.Â  In pertinent part, the agreement reads as follows:

(b) The parties anticipate that Husband may be entitled to certain Social Security benefits, although neither is certain as to the amount of such benefits.Â  In the event that Husband elects to receive such benefits at the age of 62, then and in that event, Wife shall receive one-third (1/3) of each monthly benefit check to which Husband is entitled, from and following the Husbandâ€™s attainment of the age of 62 years and his election to receive such benefits.Â  Husband shall not, however, be obligated to elect to receive early benefits.Â  In the event that Husband waits to elect to receive Social Security benefits until the age of 65 years, then and in that event, Wife shall receive one-half (1/2) of each monthly benefit check to which Husband is entitled, from and following the Husbandâ€™s attainment of the age of 65 years and his election to receive such benefits.Â  In either event, any payments to Wife under the terms of this provision regarding division of Social Security benefits shall be construed only as a property settlement, and shall not in any way be considered or construed as alimony.Â  

(Emphasis added).Â  Â Â 
This court denied Husbandâ€™s appeal from the divorce decree â€œto â€˜revise and set aside the decree as it pertain[ed] to the award of alimony, and the equitable distribution of the property.â€™â€Â  Simmons v. Simmons, No. 92-UP-104 (Ct. App. May 28, 1992).[2]Â  Husband attained the age of 62 in 1994 and the age of 65 in 1997.Â  In December 2003, because Husband had failed to remit any portion of his Social Security benefits as required by the agreement, Wife filed a petition for a rule to show cause, requesting Husband account to her for the accrued Social Security benefits due her.Â  Husband then filed a Rule 60(b)(4), SCRCP, motion requesting relief from judgment, asserting the family court lacked subject-matter jurisdiction to divide his Social Security benefits.Â  The family court denied Husbandâ€™s motion.[3]Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OFÂ  review
In appeals from the family court, this court has authority to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  This broad scope of review, however, does not require us to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  We are mindful that the family court, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002). Â Nevertheless, we are not constrained by the family courtâ€™s conclusions as to questions of law. Â See Moriarity v. Garden Sanctuary Church, 341 S.C. 320, 327, 534 S.E.2d 672, 675 (2000); See also McDuffie v. McDuffie, 308 S.C. 401, 410, 418 S.E.2d 331, 333 (Ct. App. 1992).
Law/ Analysis
Husband asserts the family court erred in denying his motion for relief from judgment because the Social Security Act (the Act) provides Social Security benefits â€œshall not be transferable or assignable.â€ 42 U.S.C. Â§ 407(a) (1998).Â  Further, Husband claims the property settlement agreement approved in the divorce decree amounts to an assignment of future Social Security benefits and thus, is violative of the Act. Therefore, he argues the family court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to divide his Social Security benefits.Â  We reluctantly agree. 
As a preliminary matter, â€œSubject matter jurisdiction refers to the courtâ€™s â€˜power to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.â€™â€ Watson v. Watson, 319 S.C. 92, 93, 460 S.E.2d 394, 395 (1995) (quoting Dove v. Gold Kist, Inc., 314 S.C. 235, 237-38, 442 S.E.2d 598, 600 (1994)). Â Section 20-7- 420(2) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003) grants the family court the exclusive jurisdiction â€œ[t]o hear and determine actions: [f]or divorce a vinculo matrimonii . . . and in other marital litigation between the parties, and for settlement of all legal and equitable rights of the parties in the actions in and to the real and personal property of the marriage.â€ (emphasis added); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2003) (stating the family court does not have jurisdiction to apportion nonmarital property).
Under Rule 60 (b)(4), SCRCP, a court may set aside a judgment more than one year after its rendition if it is void for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction. Thomas & Howard Co. v. T.W. Graham & Co., 318 S.C. 286, 291, 457 S.E.2d 340, 343 (1995); McDaniel v. U.S. Fidelity Guar. Co., 324 S.C. 639, 644, 478 S.E.2d 868, 871 (Ct. App. 1996). Although, Rule 60(b) requires the motion be made within a reasonable time after the entry of the judgment, wife has not claimed Husbandâ€™s motion was untimely.
Under the Supremacy Clause of the United States Constitution, Article VI, South Carolina law must defer to the Actâ€™s statutory scheme for allocating benefits.Â  See Hisquierdo v. Hisquierdo, 439 U.S. 572, 582 (1979) (ruling states must defer to the federal statutory scheme for allocating Railroad Retirement Act benefits insofar as terms of federal law require).Â  The Act provides a comprehensive scheme as to how Social Security benefits are to be awarded to divorced spouses.Â  Cruise v. Cruise, 374 S.E.2d 882, 883 (N.C. Ct. App. 1989) (finding the trial courtâ€™s order requiring husband to share one-half of his benefits with wife contradicted the Supreme Courtâ€™s rationale in Hisquierdo).Â  
The Act also provides: 

The right of any person to any future payment under this subchapter shall not be transferable or assignable, at law or in equity, and none of the monies paid or payable or rights existing under this subchapter shall be subject to execution, levy, attachment, garnishment, or other legal process, or to the operation of any bankruptcy or insolvency law.Â  

42 U.S.C. Â§ 407(a).Â  The Act further declares that â€œ[n]o other provision of law . . . may be construed to limit, supersede, or otherwise modify the provisions of this section except to the extent that it does so by express reference to this section.â€Â  42 U.S.C. Â§ 407(b).Â  While Â§ 659 of the Act permits reassignment of Social Security benefits to fulfill alimony obligations, it expressly excludes from the definition of alimony â€œany payment or transfer of property by an individual to the spouse or a former spouse of the individual in compliance with any community property settlement, equitable distribution of property, or other division of property between spouses or former spouses.â€ 42 U.S.C. Â§ 659(i)(3)(B)(ii). Â See Gentry v. Gentry, 938 S.W. 2d 231 (Ark. 1997) (discussing this provision).
South Carolina courts have not directly considered whether family courts may divide Social Security benefits in property distributions.Â  However, the United States Supreme Court found Â§ 407(a) imposed a â€œbroad bar against the use of legal process to reach all Social Security benefits.â€Â  Philpott v. Essex County Welfare Bd., 409 U.S. 413, 417 (1973). Â Â Â Â Furthermore, other jurisdictions have consistently held the Act preempts state courts from treating Social Security benefits as property.Â  See Gentry, 938 S.W.2d at 232; Johnson v. Johnson, 726 So. 2d 393, 394-95 (Fla. Ct. App. 1999); In re Marriage of Boyer, 538 N.W.2d 293, 295 (Iowa 1995); Sherry v. Sherry, 701 P.2d 265, 270 (Idaho Ct. App. 1985) (citing Flemming v. Nester, 363 U.S. 603 (1960)); Cruise, 374 S.E.2d at 884; Kluck v. Kluck, 561 N.W.2d 263, 270 (N.D. 1997); Kirk v. Kirk, 577 A.2d 976, 980 (R.I. 1990); In re the Marriage of Zahm, 978 P.2d 498, 501 (Wash. 1999).Â  The thrust of these decisions is that state courts are without power to take any action to enforce a private agreement dividing future payments of Social Security when such an agreement violates the statutory prohibition against transfer or assignment of future benefits.Â  
Clearly, the import of the Actâ€™s antiassignment clause is to make social security nonmarital in property divisions. Kluck, 561 N.W.2d at 270. Â Because the Act preempts state law, the family court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to divide Husbandâ€™s Social Security benefits in a property distribution. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(5) (â€œ[t]he court does not have jurisdiction or authority to apportion nonmarital property.â€). Inasmuch as the family court did not have subject matter jurisdiction over Husbandâ€™s Social Security benefits, it could not approve the settlement agreement dividing such benefits. Â See Boulter v. Boulter, 930 P.2d 112 (Nev. 1997) (holding an agreement incorporated into a divorce decree purporting to require husband to pay one-half of his Social Security benefits to his former wife was invalid and neither the Nevada Supreme Court, nor the trial court could order its enforcement.); Gentry, 938 S.W.2d at 232 (finding agreement to divide social security benefits â€œamounts to a transfer or assignment of future benefits prohibited by Section 407 and therefore was invalid and unenforceable when signedâ€). It is axiomatic that an order entered by a court without subject matter jurisdiction is utterly void. Â Coon v. Coon, 356 S.C. 342, 347, 588 S.E.2d 624, 627 (Ct. App. 2003), affâ€™d as modified, 364 S.C. 563, 614 S.E.2d 616 (2005). Â Moreover, a lack of subject matter jurisdiction may be raised at any time. Â Hallums v. Bowens, 318 S.C. 1, 3, 428 S.E.2d 894, 895 (Ct. App. 1993). Â Additionally, a court lacking subject-matter jurisdiction cannot enforce its own decrees. Â Id.
In her petition for rehearing, Wife argues the holding in Coon is in conflict with our holding in this case. We disagree. Â In Coon, our supreme court held that the Uniformed Services Former Spousesâ€™ Protection Act (USFSPA), 10 U.S.C.A. Â§ 1408 (1998) â€œexpresses no intention on Congressâ€™s part to pre-empt state court jurisdiction,â€ and that the extent of the family courtâ€™s jurisdiction over military retirement benefits is a matter of South Carolina law. 364 S.C. at 568, 614 S.E.2d at 618. Â Unlike USFSPA, Congress has in the Social Security Act expressed its intent to pre-empt state court jurisdiction regarding Social Security benefits. 
In Hisquierdo, the United States Supreme Court held that the Supremacy Clause precluded Californiaâ€™s community property laws from overcoming the Federal Railroad Retirement Act. Â 439 U. S. at 582.Â  The court equated railroad retirement benefits to Social Security benefits and concluded federal railroad retirement benefits were not subject to distribution in divorce. Â Id. Â Likewise, in Philpott, the United States Supreme Court held that the provisions of Â§ 407 barring the use of â€œany legal processâ€Â  to reachÂ  social security benefits bars all claims, to include a claim of the state of New Jersey. Â 409 U.S. at 417.Â  
In her petition for rehearing, Wife also argues Price v. Price, 325 S.C. 379, 480 S.E.2d 92 (Ct. App. 1996) is identical to the case sub judice. We believe the cases are distinguishable. We note that Price concerned the division of military retirement benefits, which are not expressly exempt by statute from being classified as marital property for equitable division purposes. Â On the other hand, Social Security benefits are expressly excluded under Â§Â§ 407 and 659 of the Act from being classified as marital property.
Finally, Wife argues, and as the family court found, that Â§ 407 was not implicated by the facts of this case because the case sub judice does not involve the transfer or assignment of Social Security benefits.Â  The family court reasoned that â€œonce [Husband] received his benefits, he is free to dispose of such funds as he deems fitâ€ without the intervention of the Social Security Administration. Â This argument is without merit.Â  Clearly, the divorce decree itself purports to divide Husbandâ€™s Social Security benefits pursuant to the agreement of the parties.Â  Moreover, the fact that Husband voluntarily agreed to pay Wife part of his Social Security benefits is of no significance. See Gentry, 938 S.W.2d at 233 (finding a property settlement agreement, which awarded wife one-half of her husbandâ€™s future Social Security benefits as he received them, was unenforceable although voluntarily entered); Boulter, 930 P.2d at 114 (holding the Actâ€™s prohibition against transferring future benefits preempted state action approving an agreement between a husband and wife to split their future Social Security benefits equally); See also Ellender v. Schweiker, 575 F.Supp. 59 (S.D.N.Y. 1983) (Congressâ€™s clear interpretation of prohibition against transfer or assignment of benefits compels strict interpretation of that clause to prohibit voluntary, as well as involuntary transfers or assignments).[4] Â By analogy our supreme court, in discussing the limitation on military retirement benefits under Â§ 1408(e)(1), stated the â€œlimitation applies whether the non-military spouse receives payments directly from the Department of Defense, from the service member spouse, or a combination of the two.â€ Â Coon, 364 S.C. at 567, 614 S.E.2d at 617.
 CONCLUSION
Although we are sympathetic to Wifeâ€™s claim, Social Security benefits simply cannot be divided in an equitable distribution award. Â Because Congress preempted the Social Security arena, state courts do not have subject-matter jurisdiction to mandate distribution of such benefits whether by agreement or otherwise.Â  Therefore, the family courtâ€™s denial of Husbandâ€™s Rule 60(b)(4), SCRCP, motion is hereby
REVERSED.
HUFF AND WILLIAMS, JJ., CONCUR.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument, pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â  
[2] In that appeal, Husband did not raise the issue of subject-matter jurisdiction.Â  
[3] The family court order indicated it denied a motion to compel by Wife, but the record on appeal does not indicate the pertinence of the motion. 
[4] A 2003 amendment to 38 U.S.C. Â§ 5301 dealing with veteransâ€™ benefits states: â€œThis paragraph is intended to clarify that, in any case where a beneficiary entitled to compensation, pension, or dependency and indemnity compensation enters into an agreement with another person under which agreement such other person acquires for consideration the right to receive such benefits by payment of such compensation, pension, or dependency and indemnity compensation, as the case may be . . . such agreement shall be deemed to be an assignment and is prohibited.â€

title: Queenâ€™s Grant II Horizontal Property Regime v. Greenwood Development
description: This case, involving cross-appeals, concerns repair of a private road and maintenance assessments for a horizontal property regime.  The regime argues that the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment for the developer on the regime's request for a declaratory judgment that the amended restrictive covenants are invalid.  The developer has also appealed and argues that the circuit court erred in denying summary judgment as to the regime's claim for recovery of funds it expended on road repair.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Queenâ€™s Grant II Horizontal Property Regime, Appellant-Respondent,
v.
Greenwood Development Corporation, d/b/a Palmetto Dunes Resort, Inc.,
Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Thomas Kemmerlin, Master â€“ In â€“ Equity
Curtis L. Coltrane, Master â€“ In â€“ Equity

Opinion No. 4101Â Â Â 
Heard January 10, 2006 â€“ Filed April 10, 2006 

AFFIRMED IN RESULT IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
Â DISMISSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Edward E. Bullard, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant-Respondent. 
Joseph R. Barker, of Hilton Head Island, for Respondent-Appellant. 
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  We are presented with cross-appeals involving the Queenâ€™s Grant II Horizontal Property Regime on Hilton Head Island in Beaufort County, South Carolina. Queenâ€™s Grant II is part of a series of horizontal property regimes in a resort known as Palmetto Dunes.Â  Queenâ€™s Grant II appeals from an order dismissing two of its three causes of action.Â  On appeal, Queenâ€™s Grant II limits its challenge to the dismissal of its claim for prospective declaratory relief regarding the efficacy of an amendment to restrictive covenants concerning assessments for maintenance in Palmetto Dunes.Â  Greenwood Development Corporation, the owner of Palmetto Dunes, appeals: (1) from the denial of its motion for summary judgment as to Queenâ€™s Grant IIâ€™s claim for breach of contract for failure to repair a road within the Queenâ€™s Grant II regime; and (2) from the denial of its motion for attorney fees and costs.Â  We affirm in result in part and reverse in part with respect to the dismissal of Queenâ€™s Grant IIâ€™s declaratory judgment claim.Â  We affirm the denial of Greenwood Developmentâ€™s motion for attorney fees and costs.Â  We elect not to entertain, and thus dismiss, Greenwood Developmentâ€™s interlocutory appeal from the denial of its summary judgment motion, and we remand.[1]  
Although this case involves many issues, primarily related to restrictive covenants and tangentially to horizontal property law, the essence of our holding is that a developer may reserve to himself, in his sole discretion, the right to amend restrictive covenants running with the land or impose new restrictive covenants running with the land, provided five conditions are met: (1) the right to amend the covenants or impose new covenants must be unambiguously set forth in the original declaration of covenants; (2) the developer, at the time of the amended or new covenants, must possess a sufficient property interest in the development; (3) the developer must strictly comply with the amendment procedure as set forth in the declaration of covenants; (4) the developer must provide notice of amended or new covenants in strict accordance with the declaration of covenants and as otherwise may be provided by law; and (5) the amended or new covenants must not be unreasonable, indefinite, or contravene public policy.Â  
FACTS / PROCEDURAL HISTORY
 I.
Palmetto Dunes is a real estate resort development that includes multiple horizontal property regimes located on Hilton Head Island in Beaufort County, South Carolina.Â  The development consists of various single and multi-family residences, commercial establishments, and resort facilities.Â  The initial developer of Palmetto Dunes was Palmetto Dunes Resort, Inc. (Palmetto Dunes Resort), a subsidiary of Phipps Land Company, Inc.Â  
Between 1968 and 1972, Palmetto Dunes Resort filed and recorded various covenants relating to contemplated single-family and multi-family developments throughout Palmetto Dunes.Â  The Declaration of Covenants,[2] recorded in 1972, sets forth various rights, conditions, and restrictions concerning â€œall multi-family dwelling areas within Palmetto Dunes,â€ including â€œlands conveyed in the future in Palmetto Dunes.â€Â  The Queenâ€™s Grant II Horizontal Property Regime became subject to the Declaration of Covenants when it was created in 1974.Â  The 1972 Covenants imposed restrictions throughout Palmetto Dunes, including, for example, covenants respecting ocean front property, lagoons, ponds, lakes, and golf courses.Â  
Under the 1972 Covenants, Palmetto Dunes Resort agreed to maintain â€œcommunity areasâ€ in the resort, but only to the extent â€œsuch maintenance and services can be provided with the proceeds.â€Â  Such services were to be funded by assessing all multi-family unit owners in the resort.Â  Paragraph 22 of the 1972 Covenants provided:

In order to provide a permanent fund to maintain, landscape and repair private streets (except those located within a privately owned lot), walkways and like community areas, maintain the beachfront, lagoons and other bodies of water in a clean and orderly condition, provide for pest control when needed and in general provide those services important to the development and preservation of an attractive community appearance, and further, to maintain the privacy, security and general safety of the residential communities in Palmetto Dunes, each owner of a multi-family dwelling unit shall pay annually to [Palmetto Dunes Resort] the sum of Sixty ($60.00) Dollars per residential unit, said sum to be placed in an account and to be used exclusively for the purposes hereinabove noted.Â  From and after January 1, 1974, this annual payment may be increased each year by the percentage of increase in the consumer price index for the previous year, or at the option of [Palmetto Dunes Resort] may be increased each year up to five (5) percent of the maximum authorized payment for the previous year. 

Queenâ€™s Grant II (Queenâ€™s Grant) is one of the multi-family horizontal property regimes within Palmetto Dunes.Â  Queenâ€™s Grant consists of 81 condominium units and comprises just a small part of Palmetto Dunes.Â  Queenâ€™s Grant was created in 1974 when Palmetto Dunes Resort recorded a master deed (Master Deed) subjecting the property to the South Carolina Horizontal Property Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 27-31-10 to 300 (1991 & Supp. 2005).[3]Â  The Master Deed provides for the administration of the Queenâ€™s Grant regime in accordance with its bylaws.Â  
The Master Deed references the 1972 Covenants and provides that â€œnothing contained [in the Master Deed] shall limit the rights of Palmetto Dunes Resort, Inc., its successors or assigns, as set forth in the aforesaid Declaration.â€ The Declaration of Covenants reserved to Palmetto Dunes Resort, or its successors, the right to modify or impose additional covenants at any time in its sole discretion.Â  The Declaration of Covenants further provided that any modifications to prior covenants would apply only to units sold after the amended covenants were recorded.Â  Additionally, the Declaration of Covenants reserved to Palmetto Dunes Resort a thirty-day right of repurchase (â€œat the same price at which the highest bona-fide offer has been made for the propertyâ€) in the event any unit owner should decide to sell.Â  
Queenâ€™s Grant, as a multi-family dwelling area within Palmetto Dunes, was subject to the assessments under the 1972 Covenants to fund Palmetto Dunes Resortâ€™s maintenance obligations throughout the resort.Â  Additionally, the Master Deed creating Queenâ€™s Grant and the regimeâ€™s bylaws assign to Queenâ€™s Grant the responsibility for the maintenance of the property within its regime.[4]Â  The bylaws created the â€œCouncil of Co-Owners,â€ consisting of the unit owners within the Queenâ€™s Grant regime. The Council, in turn, is governed by a â€œBoard of Administration.â€[5]Â  This Board, on behalf of the regime, has many duties, including the â€œ[c]ollection of assessments from the co-owners . . . [and the] [c]are, upkeep and surveillance of the [Queenâ€™s Grant] Property and the Common Elements.â€Â  The bylaws further authorize the imposition of â€œperiodic assessmentsâ€ on â€œ[a]ll co-ownersâ€ to meet all regime â€œcommon expenses.â€Â  Queenâ€™s Grant thus is obligated to perform within its regime â€œ[a]ll maintenance, repair and replacement to the common elements as defined in the Master Deed.â€Â  The Master Deed defines the â€œcommon elementsâ€ broadly to include virtually every aspect of regime maintenance, including â€œthe land on which the Apartments are constructed, . . . [p]arking facilities located on the Property, . . . [and] [a]ll roads, walkways [and] paths.â€Â  
Palmetto Dunes Resort conveyed the last of the units in Queenâ€™s Grant in 1977.Â  In 1979, Palmetto Dunes Resort (through its parent company, Phipps Land Development) was sold to Greenwood Development, an unaffiliated company.Â  As successor in interest, Greenwood Development continued under the name â€œPalmetto Dunes Resortâ€ and acquired all rights of its predecessor, including those under the 1972 Covenants.Â  
Greenwood Development determined the assessments under the 1972 Covenants were insufficient to fund its maintenance duties throughout the resort.Â  Greenwood Development, in the exercise of its right to amend the covenants, consequently recorded amended covenants in 1981â€”the 1981 Covenants[6]â€”applicable to all multi-family dwelling areas in Palmetto Dunes.[7]Â  Tracking language from the 1972 Covenants, Greenwood Development made the 1981 Covenants applicable â€œto lands conveyed in the future in Palmetto Dunes by deeds or other instruments hereafter made which make reference to this Declaration of Covenants.â€Â  The 1981 Covenants are substantially similar to the 1972 Covenants, but the 1981 Covenants increase the annual maintenance assessment.Â  Article IV of the 1981 Covenants provides, in relevant part: 

In order to provide a permanent fund to maintain, landscape and repair private streets (except those located within a privately owned lot), walkways and like community areas, maintain the beachfront, lagoons and other bodies of water in a clean and orderly condition, repair damage caused by beach erosion, provide for pest control when needed and in general provide those services important to the development and preservation of an attractive community appearance, and further, to maintain the privacy, security and general safety of the residential communities in Palmetto Dunes Resort, each owner of a multi-family dwelling unit shall pay annually to Greenwood the sum of Two Hundred ($200.00) Dollars per multi-family unit or apartment, said sum to be placed in an account and to be used exclusively for the purposes hereinabove noted.Â  From and after January 1, 1982, this annual payment may be increased each year by the percentage of increase in the Consumer Price Index for the previous year, or at the option of Greenwood may be increased each year up to ten (10%) percent of the maximum authorized payment for the previous year.Â  

The 1981 Covenants left unchanged the proviso that the responsibility for maintenance and services is limited â€œto the extent such maintenance and services can be provided with the proceeds of the assessments.â€Â  Greenwood Developmentâ€™s right of repurchase of the units was also left intact in the 1981 Covenants.Â  
The 1981 Covenantsâ€”specifically the increased assessmentsâ€”were applied to Queenâ€™s Grant units sold after the covenants were recorded.Â  By 2002, all but fourteen Queenâ€™s Grant units had been transferred, and the new owners were being assessed at the higher rate.Â  Beyond recording the 1981 Covenants, Greenwood Development additionally sought to targetâ€”provide actual notice ofâ€”the 1981 Covenantsâ€™ application to individual units as they were sold by two methods:Â  (1) by specific reference to and incorporation of the 1981 Covenants into deeds transferring title; and (2) by reference to the covenants or the increased assessments in waiver agreements (Waiver Agreements) signed by the new owners.Â Â Â Â  
The Waiver Agreements were so named because they purported to waive Greenwood Developmentâ€™s preemptive right of repurchase under the covenants.Â  However, both methods were not utilized in all cases.Â  In some cases, only Waiver Agreements were utilizedâ€”referencing the 1981 Covenants or the higher rate of assessmentâ€”and in other cases, there was no Waiver Agreement, as only deeds provided notice of the 1981 Covenants.Â  Regarding units sold and purchased after the recording of the 1981 Covenants, thirty-one units have deeds and Waiver Agreements referencing the 1981 Covenants; five units have only deeds that reference the 1981 Covenants; twenty-six units have Waiver Agreements that reference the 1981 Covenants; and five units â€œreference the higher assessment of the [1981 Covenants], but not the [1981 Covenants] themselves . . . .â€ 
II. 
This lawsuit arose from a dispute over responsibility for a $175 road repair invoice.[8]Â  In December of 2000, Queenâ€™s Grant paid $175 for the road repair and demanded payment from Greenwood Development, but Greenwood Development refused.Â  Queenâ€™s Grant then brought an action for breach of contract seeking to recover the $175.Â  Queenâ€™s Grant expanded the dispute to challenge Greenwood Developmentâ€™s ability to amend the 1972 Covenants and enforce assessments under the 1981 Covenants; Queenâ€™s Grant sought a return to the lower assessment under the 1972 Covenants.Â  This relief was sought in the form of a declaratory judgment that Greenwood Development lacked the authority to amend the covenants in 1981, and therefore each co-owner in the regime should be assessed in the future pursuant to the lower fee in the 1972 Covenants.Â  The declaratory judgment claimâ€”seeking only prospective reliefâ€”is an equitable claim.Â  Finally, Queenâ€™s Grant sought a refund in an action at law of all assessments collected in excess of that due under the 1972 Covenants.Â  
Greenwood Development filed two motions for summary judgment.Â  The first motion requested summary judgment on Queenâ€™s Grantâ€™s first cause of action relating to the road repair.Â  Greenwood Developmentâ€™s second motion sought summary judgment as to the second and third causes of action regarding the maintenance assessment.Â  The circuit court issued an order granting Greenwood Developmentâ€™s second motion, but refused to grant its first motion.[9]Â  The motions for reconsideration by both parties were denied.Â  Greenwood Developmentâ€™s motion for attorney fees and costs was also denied.
Queenâ€™s Grant appeals only from the dismissal of its second cause of action seeking declaratory relief as to the unit ownersâ€™ responsibility for future assessments under the 1981 Covenants.Â  Greenwood Development cross-appeals, claiming the circuit court erred in two respects: (1) in failing to grant it summary judgment as to the breach of contract action concerning the road repair invoice; and (2) in failing to award it attorney fees and costs.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard that governs the circuit court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Pittman v. Grand Strand Entmâ€™t, Inc., 363 S.C. 531, 536, 611 S.E.2d 922, 925 (2005).Â  Summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Id.Â  On appeal, when factual matters are in dispute, all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence must be viewed in a light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id.Â  However, when the facts are not in dispute, the question before the court is one of law.Â  Dawson v. S.C. Power Co., 220 S.C. 26, 32, 66 S.E.2d 322, 325 (1951) (holding that when only one reasonable inference can be drawn from a contested issue of fact, the question becomes one of law for the court).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS 
I.
Queenâ€™s Grantâ€™s AppealÂ Â Â  
Queenâ€™s Grant acknowledges it has maintenance responsibilities on two fronts: (1) the payment of assessments to Palmetto Dunes Resort for maintenance of Palmetto Dunesâ€™ properties beyond its regime; and (2) the maintenance of its own regime property, including the common elements.Â  Queenâ€™s Grantâ€™s appeal does not involve its maintenance obligations within its regime.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-31-190 (1991) (providing that each co-owner must contribute toward the maintenance of the regime common areas).Â  Queenâ€™s Grant further does not challenge the obligation of its owners (as originally imposed in the 1972 Covenants) to pay to Greenwood Development assessments for maintenance of the common areas beyond the Queenâ€™s Grant regime.[10]Â  Queenâ€™s Grant simply wants to limit those assessments to the rate as established in the 1972 Covenants.Â  Queenâ€™s Grant, therefore, appeals from the entry of summary judgment dismissing its second cause of action seeking a declaratory judgment that all unit owners in the regime be assessed prospectively at the lower rate under the 1972 Covenants.
Although the circuit court concluded the 1981 Covenants are valid, a review of the order granting summary judgment reveals that the circuit court primarily based its decision on the equitable doctrines of estoppel and laches.[11]Â Â  

A. Circuit Courtâ€™s Grant of Summary Judgment 
  
1.Â  Estoppel Â 
  

Â â€œEstoppel arises when a party, relying upon what another has said or done, changes his position to his detriment.â€Â  Gibbs v. Kimbrell, 311 S.C. 261, 268, 428 S.E.2d 725, 729 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  A claim of estoppel includes elements for the party asserting estoppel and the party estopped.Â  E.g., Provident Life and Accident Ins. Co. v. Driver, 317 S.C. 471, 477, 451 S.E.2d 924, 928 (Ct. App. 1994) (listing the elements of equitable estoppel:Â  as to the estopped party, a misrepresentation or nondisclosure, intent to induce the other party to act, and actual or constructive knowledge of the true facts; and as to the party claiming estoppel, lack of knowledge, or means of acquiring knowledge of the true facts, reasonable reliance, and prejudicial change of position).Â  
As the circuit court found, it is a well-established principle in South Carolina that estoppel by silence arises when one party observes another dealing with his property in a manner inconsistent with his rights and makes no objection while the other party changes his position based on the partyâ€™s silence.Â  Seabrook Island Property Owners Association v. Pelzer, 292 S.C. 343, 356 S.E.2d 411 (Ct. App. 1987), supports the circuit courtâ€™s adoption of Greenwood Developmentâ€™s estoppel defense as to Queenâ€™s Grantâ€™s now-abandoned refund claim.Â  In Pelzer, the ownersâ€™ association sued to collect an unpaid annual assessment.Â  Id. at 345, 356 S.E.2d at 412.Â  The landowner counterclaimed and sought a refund of assessments paid for the years 1976 through 1983 on the basis that the assessment was invalid.Â  Id.Â  This court found in favor of the landowner in that the assessment violated the applicable restrictive covenants and bylaws, yet the court concluded the landowner was not entitled to a refund of the excess assessments paid in prior years.Â  Id. at 348, 356 S.E.2d at 414.Â  The landownerâ€™s inability to recover the excessive assessments rested in his estoppel by silence.Â  As the court observed:

[Pelzer] acquiesced in the method of assessment and paid the charges.Â  The Association expended the moneys for purposes authorized by the by-laws.Â  Pelzer received the benefit of those expenditures. He cannot now return the benefits or restore the Association to its former position.Â  . . .Â  If a party stands by and sees another dealing with his property in a manner inconsistent with his rights and makes no objection while the other changes his position, his silence is acquiescence and it estops him from later seeking relief.Â Â  

Id.  
The Pelzer courtâ€™s treatment of the estoppel defense clearly applies to Queenâ€™s Grantâ€™s efforts in the trial court to recover allegedly excessive assessments for the past two decades, a claim now abandoned.Â  But the estoppel defense does not summarily dispose of the declaratory judgment claim of Queenâ€™s Grant for prospective relief.Â  There are genuine issues of material fact concerning the application of estoppel to these facts.Â  For example, the record does not support a finding as a matter of law that Greenwood Development would be prejudiced by an adverse ruling in the declaratory judgment cause of action (that the assessments under the 1981 Covenants were not authorized), thereby requiring future assessments under the 1972 Covenants.Â  In this regard, both the 1972 Covenants and 1981 Covenants provide that Greenwood Development is responsible for providing services only to the extent the funds from unit owners covered such services.Â  Because the element of detrimental reliance may be lacking (as well as other elements), the estoppel defense does not entitle Greenwood Development to summary judgment on the declaratory judgment cause of action.Â  

  
2.Â  Laches 
  

The circuit court alternatively found that laches bars Queenâ€™s Grantâ€™s declaratory judgment cause of action seeking only prospective relief.Â  â€œâ€˜Lachesâ€™ is defined as â€˜neglect for an unreasonable and unexplained length of time, under circumstances affording opportunity for diligence, to do what in law should have been done.â€™â€Â  Gordon v. Drews, 358 S.C. 598, 612, 595 S.E.2d 864, 871 (Ct. App. 2004) (quoting Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 296, 519 S.E.2d 583, 598 (Ct. App. 1999)).Â  â€œDelay alone is not enough to constitute laches; it must be unreasonable, and the party asserting laches must show prejudice.â€Â  Gordon, 358 S.C. at 612, 595 S.E.2d at 871 (quoting Brown v. Butler, 347 S.C. 259, 265, 554 S.E.2d 431, 434 (Ct. App. 2001)).Â  
We again confront the circuit courtâ€™s blanket finding of prejudice against Greenwood Development, a finding in which Greenwood Development may seek refuge only as to the claim for a refund of past assessments.Â  For the same reason the circuit court could not properly find estoppel and grant Greenwood Development summary judgment as to the claim for prospective relief, the court erred in relying alternatively on laches to dismiss the declaratory judgment cause of action.Â  

  
3.Â  The Validity of the 1981 Covenants
  

We now turn to the merits of Queenâ€™s Grantâ€™s challenge to the validity of the 1981 Covenants.Â  The circuit court in its conclusions of law ruled that â€œthe assessment imposed under the [1981] Covenants is, as a matter of law, a valid assessment imposed pursuant to Greenwood Developmentâ€™s rights, as a successor and assign of [Palmetto Dunes Resort], pursuant to the plain and unambiguous provisions of the [1972] Covenants permitting the amendment of the [1972] Covenants.â€Â  We concur with the circuit court, with the exception of five units in Queenâ€™s Grant. 
 In South Carolina, an owner of a fee or leasehold interest in certain real property may declare the property to be subject to a horizontal property regime.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-31-30 (Supp. 2005).Â  The term horizontal is a misnomer, for a â€œcondominium is actually a vertical property regime composed of horizontal slices of airspace . . . within the vertical column.â€Â  Sea Watch Stores Ltd. Liab. Co. v. Council of Unit Owners of Sea Watch Condo., 691 A.2d 750, 753 n.1 (Md. Ct. Spec. App. 1997).Â  When land is submitted to a horizontal property regime, no new property is created, even though the structure as completed may include many floors of condominium units.Â  Id. at 753.Â  Instead, condominium statutes, like South Carolinaâ€™s Horizontal Property Act, merely created a new way to own and regulate airspace.Â  Id.Â  Condominium apartments may be bought and sold like real property.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 27-31-40 and 60 (1991).Â  Ownership in a condominium may be subject to deed restrictions and covenants like any other real property.Â  See Sea Watch, 691 A.2d at 753-54.Â  
The creation of a horizontal property regime is accomplished through compliance with the South Carolina Horizontal Property Act.Â  Section 27-31-40 of the South Carolina Code provides that once property is submitted to a condominium horizontal property regime, individual apartments may be owned, conveyed and encumbered independently of other apartments, subject to the same general principles of law governing real property.Â  See 4 S.C. Jur. Condominiums Â§ 9 (2005).Â  Apartments, for horizontal property purposes, are defined in section 27-31-20(a) (1991) as â€œa part of the property intended for any type of independent use . . . including one or more rooms or enclosed spaces . . . .â€Â Â  Each â€œco-owner,â€ or owner of an apartment in a regime, acquires â€œcondominium ownership,â€ and owns his or her individual apartment, and has a common right to share, with other co-owners, in the common areas of the property.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-31-20(c) and (d) (Supp. 2005); Â§ 27-31-60.
Property, whether subject to the Horizontal Property Act, may, of course, be governed by restrictive covenants.Â  Real covenants have been defined as â€œagreement[s] . . . to do, or refrain from doing, certain things with respect to real property.â€Â  20 Am. Jur. 2d Covenants, Conditions, and Restrictions Â§ 1 (2005).Â  Therefore, covenants, â€œin a sense are contractual in nature and bind the parties thereto in the same manner as would any other contract.â€Â  Id. (citing Seabrook Island Prop. Owners Assoc. v. Pelzer, 292 S.C. 343, 356 S.E.2d 411 (Ct. App. 1987)).Â  Restrictive covenants are construed like contracts and may give rise to actions for breach of contract.Â  17 S.C. Jur. Covenants Â§ 2 (2005) (citing Hoffman v. Cohen, 262 S.C. 71, 202 S.E.2d 363 (1974) and Manning v. City of Columbia, 297 S.C. 451, 377 S.E.2d 335 (1989)).Â  However, restrictive covenants affecting real property cannot be properly and fully understood without resort to property law. 
Restrictive covenants differ from contracts in that they â€œrun with the land,â€ meaning that they are enforceable by and against later grantees.Â  17 S.C. Jur. [6] Â Â Â Â Â Â  The document containing the 1981 Covenants is entitled â€œDECLARATION OF RIGHTS, RESTRICTIONS, CONDITIONS, ETC., WHICH CONSTITUTE COVENANTS RUNNING WITH CERTAIN LANDS WITHIN PALMETTO DUNES RESORT.â€Â  The document is subtitled, â€œCONSOLIDATED MULTI-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL COVENANTS OF GREENWOOD DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION.â€Â  It was recorded on January 19, 1981, in the office of Register of Deeds for Beaufort County in Deed Book 314 at page 505.Â  We refer to this document as the 1981 Covenants. 
[7] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We recognize that the Limited Covenants, recorded in 1982, apply only to single-family residential units and thus are inapplicable to the present dispute.Â  It appears Queenâ€™s Grant initially challenged the 1982 Covenants, confusing them with the 1981 Covenants.Â  
[8] Â Â Â Â Â Â  This street is located in the Queenâ€™s Grant regime, but we are unable to determine its precise location from the record.Â  
[9] Â Â Â Â Â Â  Queenâ€™s Grant asserts that it withdrew its cause of action for a refund of allegedly excessive assessments under the 1981 Covenants before the circuit court issued its ruling. There is nothing in the record to support this assertion.Â Â Â  Queenâ€™s Grant continued to oppose the dismissal of this cause of action, even after the circuit court granted summary judgment.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s ruling as to the assessment refund is the law of the case.Â  Â 
[10] Â Â Â Â Â  Covenants that require property owners to pay to a developer or homeownersâ€™ association assessments that have a beneficial effect on the value of the ownersâ€™ properties touch and concern land and therefore â€œrun with the land.â€Â  Harbison Cmty. Assoc., Inc. v. Mueller, 319 S.C. 99, 102, 459 S.E.2d 860, 862 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  It is undisputed that the assessments under the respective covenants to fund Greenwood Developmentâ€™s maintenance obligations of Palmetto Dunes â€œrun with the land.â€Â Â  Â Â Â  
[11] Â Â Â Â Â  The circuit courtâ€™s discussion regarding the statute of limitations applies only to the claim for a refund of assessments, which was asserted as an action at law seeking damages.Â  
[12] Â Â Â Â Â  In the area of condominium and property regime law, Florida case law is cited approvingly in jurisdictions throughout the country.Â  Indeed, when faced with unresolved questions in horizontal property law, courts often look to Florida law.Â  See Douglas Scott MacGregor, South Carolina Condominium Law Â§ 1.01 (William S. Jula ed. 1986) (â€œFlorida is the undisputed leader in the development of condominium law, and its cases are frequently cited in other states and are generally considered to have persuasive value.â€).Â  Queenâ€™s Grant does not challenge the general right of Greenwood Development to amend the 1972 Covenants; Queenâ€™s Grantâ€™s challenge in this regard is limited to the claim that the 1981 amendments are ineffective as to its co-owners because the last Queenâ€™s Grant unit was sold in 1977.
[13] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The term â€œdeclarantâ€ is often used in documents related to restrictive covenants and the creation of horizontal property regimes, as well as the corresponding rights and responsibilities of an owner-developer. In the context of horizontal property law, a declarant is â€œa grantor that establishes or joins in the creation of a declaration of condominium.â€Â  15A Am. Jur. 2d Condominiums Â§ 1 (2005). 
[14] Â Â Â Â Â  We note that the Horizontal Property Act may not be controlling here (at least not exclusively) because Greenwood Developmentâ€™s maintenance obligations under the 1972 Covenants and 1981 Covenants do not relate to the regime property of Queenâ€™s Grant; as noted, these obligations relate to resort property outside of the Queenâ€™s Grant regime.Â  Because the covenants concern responsibility for maintenance of resort property beyond the Queenâ€™s Grant regime, Greenwood Development is akin to a â€œmaster associationâ€ and is not subject to the Horizontal Property Act with regard to such property.Â  See Scott v. Sandestin Corp., 491 So. 2d 334 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1986).Â  Courts in other jurisdictions have recognized that assessments by master associations for maintenance of property outside the regime are separate from assessments by the condominium association for maintenance of its own common elements.Â  Hobson v. Hilltop Place Cmty. Assoc., 453 A.2d 841, 842 (N.H. 1982).Â  
[15] Â Â Â Â Â  Cf. Heritage Fed. Sav. & Loan Assâ€™n v. Eagle Lake & Golf Condos., 318 S.C. 535, 541, 458 S.E.2d 561, 565 (Ct. App. 1995) (holding a regime developer has the authority to amend the master deed without the consent of property owners so long as the developer specifically reserves that right in the master deed).
[16] Â Â Â Â Â  The 1972 Covenants contain the same provision.
[17] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  At common law, a â€œcovenantâ€ generally referred to a contract under seal.Â  20 Am. Jur. 2d Covenants, Conditions, and Restrictions Â§ 2 (2005).Â  In South Carolina, some distinctions between contracts under seal and other contracts remain, such as the rule that a covenant under seal may not be set aside for lack of consideration in the absence of fraud.Â  Id.; Jackson v. Walters, 246 S.C. 486, 493, 144 S.E.2d 422, 425 (1965). 
[18] Â Â Â Â Â  The common law rule is as follows:Â  â€œNo interest is good unless it must vest, if at all, no later than twenty-one years after some life in being at the creation of the interest.â€Â  Abrams v. Templeton, 320 S.C. 325, 327, 465 S.E.2d 117, 119 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  
[19] Â Â Â Â Â  Greenwood Development has consistently assessed the fourteen remaining units at the lower rate included in the 1972 Covenants.Â  
[20] Â Â Â Â Â  Edge v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 366 S.C. 511, 517, 623 S.E.2d 387, 390 (2005) (entertaining a discretionary appeal of a motion to dismiss in the interest of judicial economy because a related issue in a cross-appeal was properly before the court); Brown v. County of Berkeley, 366 S.C. 354, 362 n.5, 622 S.E.2d 533, 538 n.5 (2005) (holding that interlocutory orders may be considered on appeal when they are companion to reviewable issues, but finding the motions to dismiss unreviewable because they lacked a sufficient â€œnexus or companionshipâ€ to justify the exercise of immediate appellate review); Morris v. Anderson County, 349 S.C. 607, 610-11, 564 S.E.2d 649, 651 (2002) (holding that the appellate court may, as a matter of discretion, consider an unappealable order along with an appealable issue where such a ruling will avoid unnecessary litigation, but declining to address the appeal based on concerns of creating an impermissible advisory ruling); Pitts v. Jackson Natâ€™l Life Ins. Co., 352 S.C. 319, 338, 574 S.E.2d 502, 511-12 (Ct. App. 2002) (entertaining an appeal from a denial of summary judgment because it was so closely connected with other issues properly before the court).Â  
[21] Â Â Â Â Â  We do not reach the underlying question of whether the attorney fee provision is enforceable at all.Â  There is no attorney fee provision in the 1972 Declaration of Covenants.Â  The provision was added in 1981 presumably pursuant to Greenwood Developmentâ€™s rights as Declarant to impose additional covenants running with the land â€œwithin the multi-family residential areas in Palmetto Dunes.â€Â  Because Queenâ€™s Grant is not a â€œviolatorâ€ and Greenwood Development is thus not entitled to an award of attorney fees, we need not decide whether a declarant may unilaterally impose a one-sided attorney fee provision under the guise of a covenant running with the land.Â  Cf.Â  Harbison Cmty. Assoc., Inc. v. Mueller, 319 S.C. 99, 102, 459 S.E.2d 860, 862 (Ct. App. 1995) (covenants that touch and concern the land have a beneficial effect on the property and are said to â€œrun with the landâ€); 20 Am. Jur. 2d Covenants, Conditions, and Restrictions Â§ 1 (2005) (defining a restrictive covenant as â€œan agreement . . . to do, or refrain from doing, certain things with respect to real propertyâ€).Â Â Â

Cody Discount v. Audrey Merritt
