THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Cody Discount, Inc., Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Audrey Merritt, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Master-In-Equity

Opinion No.Â  4102
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed April 10, 2006

AFFIRMED in part, REVERSED in part, and REMANDED


  
    
      
        Jeffrey Falkner Wilkes, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        Laura W. H. Teer, & Robert C. Childs, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  Audrey Merritt appeals a master-in-equityâ€™s decision holding that Cody Discount, Inc. was entitled to evict her from its real property following her default on an installment land contract.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
On October 27, 1987, Audrey Merritt entered into an installment land contract with Martin and Wilma Baker to purchase a manufactured home and a 100 x 170 foot lot for $44,500.Â  The Bakers informed Merritt that she did not need to file the contract until the property was paid for in full.Â  The contract contained clauses that made the purchase contingent on payments of $450 dollars a month and maintenance of credit life insurance on the premises.Â  The contract further stated that failure to comply with these conditions would entitle the seller to repossess the premises and retain all payments as rent.Â  
Merritt testified the Bakers later informed her the insurance provision would be satisfied as long as she maintained insurance on the premises themselves.Â  Accordingly, she never purchased the credit life policy called for in the contract.Â  She also submitted payments after they were due on several occasions, but the Bakers always accepted the payments and never declared the contract in default.Â  Although she was behind on payments to the Bakers, all past due amounts were satisfied when the Bakers later sold the property to Riley and Doris Jones in May 1989.
After the Joneses purchased the property, Merritt continued making payments of $450 a month.Â  Merritt admitted she also made late payments from time to time to the Joneses, but, as with the Bakers, the Joneses always accepted the payments and never declared her in default.Â  Cody Discount later purchased the property through a bond for title from Mr. Jones in March 2000.Â  However, the property was not actually in Cody Discountâ€™s name until Cody took out a mortgage to pay for the property in May 2002.Â  
From March 2000 until January 2002, Ms. Merritt continued to make her payments to Mr. Jones who would, in turn, endorse them over to Cody Discount.Â  In January 2002, Merritt made her last payment to Mr. Jones.Â  At this time, she and Mr. Jones were in negotiations about a payoff amount.Â  Merritt testified that she was going to pay off the house with settlement money stemming from her first husbandâ€™s death.Â  
Shortly after Cody Discount acquired title to the property, it brought an action in magistrateâ€™s court to have Merritt evicted from her property based on her payment history.Â  Soon after the hearing, Janet Cody, as President of Cody Discount, sent Merritt a letter stating that as of October 15, 2002, Merritt had an outstanding balance of $793.17.Â  The letter further explained that interest would continue to accrue and a late fee of $20 would be added each pay period until the balance was paid in full.
On December 20, 2002, Merritt sent a response to Cody Discount via certified mail expressing her desire to pay the balance and tendering a check for $833.17.Â  Although Janet Cody received the letter, the check was never cashed because Cody Discount alleged Merritt owed more than she tendered.Â  It is somewhat unclear exactly how much Cody Discount alleges Merritt still owes as there are several different amounts appearing in the record.Â  For instance, there is the previously mentioned letter drafted by Janet Cody which states a balance of $737.17, Cody Discountâ€™s complaint, which states Merritt was delinquent in the amount $793.17 but owed $1,247 dollars in late fees ($2040.17), while at trial it appears Cody Discount was trying to evict Merritt for owing $2,873.[1] 
In addition to Merrittâ€™s late payments, Cody Discount argued before the master that it would be impossible for it to convey the property to Merritt as intended in the original contract.Â  This claim of impossibility arises from a series of ordinances passed by Greenville County in 2000, which prevent mobile homes from having direct access to a public street or highway and require them to have access via an interior roadway.Â  Although Merritt has always accessed the property over the same drive and Cody Discount was aware of her contract to purchase the mobile home and lot when they entered into the bond for title with Mr. Jones, Janet Cody stated that she never thought about having to deed her a right of way to use the drive.Â  Through her testimony, Janet Cody made it clear that she did not want to grant Merritt an easement down the existing road because it would â€œruin the value of our property.â€[2]Â  Cody did state that she would be willing to grant Merritt an easement around the property, but Merritt would have to construct a road because none currently exists in that location.
On October 26, 2004, the master-in-equity issued an order ruling partially in each partyâ€™s favor.Â  Although the master found Merritt defaulted in making payments to each of the owners, he also noted that Merritt had almost paid the entire original balance on the contract.Â  The master went on to rule that forfeiture of the mobile home should be relieved, but forfeiture of the lot should be granted based on the previously mentioned defaults and the fact that Cody Discount could not deed the lot to Merritt without granting her additional interests that would significantly affect its propertyâ€™s value.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Actions to foreclose or cancel an instrument are actions in equity.Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 324 S.C. 570, 576, 479 S.E.2d 510, 513 (1996) (citations omitted). In an action in equity, while this Court is free to take its own view of the preponderance of the evidence, this does not require us to disregard the findings of the trial judge who saw and heard the witnesses and, accordingly, was in a better position to judge their credibility.Â  Donnan v. Mariner, 339 S.C. 621, 626, 529 S.E.2d 754, 757 (Ct. App. 2000).
LAW / ANALYSIS
On appeal, Merritt argues the master-in-equity erred in holding that â€œit was fair and equitable that [her] right in the real property should be forfeited and further, that any forfeiture should not be relieved.â€Â  We agree.
The courts of South Carolina have long held that forfeitures or penalties are not favored in either law or equity.Â  Lewis v. Premium Inv. Corp., 351 S.C. 167, 172, 568 S.E.2d 361, 363 (2002); Ducworth v. Neely, 319 S.C. 158, 162, 459 S.E.2d 896, 899 (Ct. App. 1995); see also Litchfield Co. of South Carolina, Inc. v. Kiriakides, 290 S.C. 220, 349 S.E.2d 344 (Ct. App. 1986); Alexander v. Herndon, 84 S.C. 181, 65 S.E.2d 1048 (1909).Â  Concomitantly, â€œa provision in an installment land contract declaring forfeiture in the event of purchaser default can, in particular circumstances, constitute a penalty.â€Â  Lewis, 351 S.C. at 172, 568 S.E.2d at 364.
In Lewis, our supreme court held that in certain contractual instances where a stipulated sum (in the event of default) constitutes a penalty, â€œit would be inequitable to enforce the forfeiture provision without first allowing the purchaser an opportunity to redeem the installment contract by paying the entire purchase price.â€Â  Id.Â  As noted in the masterâ€™s order, there are a number of case-specific factors to consider in making such a determination.Â  These factors include the amount of equity the purchaser has accumulated, the length and number of defaults, the amount of forfeiture, the speed in which equity is sought, and the amount of money the purchaser would forfeit in relation to the purchase price of the property.Â  Id. at 174, n.5, 568 S.E.2d at 364, n.5.
Presumably based in part on these factors, the master-in-equity found that Cody Discountâ€™s right to obtain ownership of Merrittâ€™s home should be relieved, but that its right to repossess the land should not be relieved.Â  While we agree with the master as to the mobile home, after a review of the record we find the master should have granted Merritt the right to redeem the installment contract by paying the remainder of the purchase price.Â  While Cody Discount makes much of the fact that granting Merritt an easement across the preexisting road, as her only means of access to the property, would â€œsignificantlyâ€ affect the value of its property, there is no evidence in the record to quantify such a claim.
Although it is true that Merritt has made late payments on and off since the inception of the land sale contract, it is also true that all of the property owners, including Cody Discount, continued to accept the payments without declaring her in default.Â  It was only when Merritt was within approximately $1,000 of paying off an original contract price of $44,500 that Cody Discount decided it would no longer be advantageous for them to transfer the property and thus they brought the current action.
As such, we affirm the masterâ€™s decision as to the mobile home, reverse as to forfeiture of the lot, and remand for a determination of the amount Merritt owes to redeem the property. 
AFFIRMED in part, REVERSED in part, and REMANDED. [3]
BEATTY, SHORT and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Janet Cody attributed the incorrect balances to miscalculations based on a faulty amortization schedule.Â  
[2] The existing road runs though the middle of the approximately 10-acre parcel Cody Discount purchased from the Joneses.Â  Although Janet Cody on more than one occasion suggested that granting Merritt an easement would devalue her property, no evidence was presented to quantify the alleged decrease in value. 
[3] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Arthur v. Sexton Dental Clinic
description: In this medical malpractice action, Appellants appeal the circuit court's order, arguing the court erred in:  (1) failing to set aside a scheduling order; (2) limiting discovery; (3) denying their Batson motion; and (4) excluding certain witnesses at trial.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Ellis Arthur and Barbara Arthur as Wife, next friend, and companion,
Appellants,
v.
Sexton Dental Clinic, and Leigh Westraad and Lisa Ann
Eagerton, as personal representatives of the Estate of Dr. H.L. Eagerton, Jr. and his associates A-Z; SC
JUA, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4103
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Heard September 13, 2005 â€“ Filed April 10, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Ellis and Barbara Arthur, of Myrtle Beach, pro se, for Appellants.[1]
Saunders M. Bridges, Jr. and Amy Anderson Wise, of Florence, for Respondents.
      
    
  

 BEATTY, J.:Â  In this medical malpractice action, Ellis Arthur and Barbara Arthur (Appellants) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s order, arguing the court erred in:Â  (1) failing to set aside a scheduling order; (2) limiting discovery; (3) denying their Batson motion; and (4) excluding certain witnesses at trial.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On May 8 1995, Ellis Arthur visited the Sexton Dental Clinic with a toothache. Â Dr. Sojourner examined Arthur and extracted Arthurâ€™s tooth. Arthur returned to the Sexton Dental Clinic on May 10, 1995, because he continued to experience pain.Â  Dr. Hester examined Arthur, did not see any problems, and sent Arthur home. Â Arthur began to experience trismus,[2] and therefore returned to the Sexton Dental Clinic once again on May 12, 1995. Â Dr. Sojourner examined Arthur, discovered an infection, and prescribed antibiotics. Â Arthur was hospitalized on May 16 for the infection and remained hospitalized for approximately two weeks. Â Arthur continues to suffer from pain in his throat and jaw. Â In addition, he has trouble swallowing food, and cannot speak clearly.Â  
On April 30, 1998, Arthur and his wife filed this action against the Sexton Dental Clinic, Dr. Eagerton,[3] and some associates (Respondents) for medical malpractice. Â Shortly after answering the Appellantsâ€™ complaint, Respondentsâ€™ counsel served Appellants with interrogatories and requests for the production of documents.Â  When responses were not completed in a timely manner, Respondents moved to compel Appellants to answer the discovery. Â After a hearing, Circuit Court Judge Sidney Floyd granted the motion and ordered Appellants to respond within sixty days and to specifically address information regarding their expert witnesses.
On July 26, 2000, Respondents retained new counsel.Â  The new counsel soon became concerned regarding the limited amount of discovery that had been completed in the two years since the case was filed.Â  As a result, counsel forwarded a proposed scheduling order to Circuit Court Judge James E. Brogdon, Jr., the Chief Administrative Judge, on November 9, 2000. Â Counsel also forwarded a copy of the proposed scheduling order to Appellantsâ€™ counsel. Â A few days later, Judge Brogdonâ€™s law clerk called Appellantsâ€™ counsel to discuss the proposed scheduling order and left a voicemail message concerning the order. Â In addition, Respondentsâ€™ counsel mailed Appellantsâ€™ counsel a letter inquiring whether Appellants would agree to the proposed scheduling order and stating that if Appellants did not consent, Judge Brogdon would schedule a conference to discuss the matter. Â After receiving no response from Appellantsâ€™ counsel, Judge Brogdon signed the scheduling order on December 19, 2000. Â The order, which was filed on January 4, 2001, limited discovery to forty-five days.
On September 19, 2001, Circuit Court Judge J. Michael Baxley held a hearing concerning the partiesâ€™ pending motions. Â The motions included the following: Â (1) Respondentsâ€™ motion to compel discovery; (2) Respondentsâ€™ motions for summary judgment; (3) Appellantsâ€™ motion to set aside the scheduling order; (4) Appellantsâ€™ motion to amend the pleadings to include additional doctors; and (5) Appellantsâ€™ motion to compel the depositions of certain witnesses. Â At the beginning of the hearing, Judge Baxley notified the parties that he planned to defer Appellantsâ€™ motion to set aside the scheduling order to Judge Brogdon.Â  Judge Baxley stated â€œI am not the chief administrative judgeâ€ and â€œIâ€™m going to defer to him and Iâ€™ll let you go back in the back and have a telephone conference with Judge Brogdon.â€ Â Appellants objected, arguing the â€œscheduling order is a matter that needs to be heard and ruled on by the Court because . . . the other motions . . . fall from that.â€ Â Judge Baxley refused to hear the scheduling order motion. Â However, he heard Respondentsâ€™ motions and Appellantsâ€™ motion to amend the pleadings.Â  He deferred Appellantsâ€™ motion to compel depositions until Judge Brogdon ruled on the scheduling order motion. 
Prior to the telephone conference with Judge Brogdon, Judge Baxley denied Respondentsâ€™ motion for summary judgment. Â Judge Baxley, however, granted Respondentsâ€™ motion to compel discovery and ordered Appellants to produce dental records, prescription records, tax returns, and an itemized statement of damages within ten days. Â In addition, Judge Baxley denied Appellantsâ€™ motion to amend the pleadings stating, â€œ[i]t would be significantly prejudicial to these new parties and to the existing defendants to allow this amendment at this very late hour.â€ 
During the telephone conference, Judge Brogdon denied Appellantsâ€™ motion to set aside the scheduling order. Â After the telephone conference, Judge Baxley resumed the proceeding and heard Appellantsâ€™ motion to compel the deposition of certain witnesses.Â  Because the witnesses were not properly identified prior to the end of discovery as provided in the scheduling order, Judge Baxley denied this motion. Â Appellants were, however, permitted to depose Dr. Eagerton. 
On January 14, 2002, Judge Brogdon presided over the jury trial in the case. Â During jury selection, Appellants challenged two of Respondentsâ€™ peremptory strikes based on Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986).Â  Judge Brogdon held a Batson hearing and ruled the strikes were proper given there was no showing of pretext. 
After the Batson hearing, Appellantsâ€™ counsel renewed his motions.Â  Judge Brogdon considered these motions as well as Respondentsâ€™ pre-trial motions, which included:Â  (1) Respondentsâ€™ motion seeking to exclude certain evidence due to Appellantsâ€™ failure to comply with discovery within the ten-day time frame set forth in Judge Baxleyâ€™s order; and (2) Respondentsâ€™ motion to exclude the testimony of Appellantsâ€™ witnesses, Dr. Fish, Dr. Graham, and Dr. Chewning.Â  Judge Brogdon granted Respondentsâ€™ motion and, as a consequence, excluded evidence Appellants failed to timely produce. Specifically, Judge Brogdon excluded the testimony of Drs. Fish, Graham, and Chewning. 
Ultimately, the jury rendered a verdict in favor of Respondents.Â  Judge Brogdon denied Appellantsâ€™ post-trial motions. Â This appeal followed. Â 
DISCUSSION
I.Â  Discovery
Appellants contend the circuit court erred in issuing the scheduling order outside the presence of Appellantsâ€™ counsel.Â  In the alternative, Appellants assert the circuit court erred in failing to set aside the scheduling order and declining to extend the time for discovery.[4] Â We disagree.
â€œThe trial courtâ€™s rulings on discovery matters will not be disturbed on appeal absent a clear abuse of discretion.â€ Belk of Spartanburg, S.C., Inc. v. Thompson, 337 S.C. 109, 126-27, 522 S.E.2d 357, 366 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law or, when grounded in factual conclusions, is without evidentiary support.â€ Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 389, 529 S.E.2d 528, 539 (2000).
Under certain conditions, the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure permit trial courts to issue scheduling orders for discovery.Â  Rule 16(a)(5) provides that upon motion of the parties, the court â€œmay in its discretion or upon motion of any party direct the attorneys for the parties to appear before itâ€ for a pre-trial hearing to consider the limitation of time allowed for discovery.Â  In addition, Rule 26(f) provides the following: 

[T]he court may direct the attorneys for the parties to appear before it for a conference on the subject of discovery.Â  The court shall do so upon motion by the attorneys for any party if the motion includes: (1) A statement of the issues as they then appear; (2) A proposed plan and schedule of discovery; (3) Any limitations proposed to be placed on discovery; (4) Any other proposed orders with respect to discovery; and (5) A statement showing that the attorney making the motion has made a reasonable effort to reach agreement with opposing attorneys on the matters set forth in the motion.

Rule 26(f), SCRCP.Â  The court may combine a pre-trial hearing, authorized by Rule 16, and a discovery conference, authorized by Rule 26(f).Â  Id.Â Â Â  
In this case, Respondentsâ€™ counsel forwarded a proposed scheduling order to Judge Brogdon on November 9, 2000, along with a brief letter explaining his concerns regarding the limited amount of discovery that had been completed.[5]Â  After unsuccessfully attempting to contact Appellantsâ€™ counsel, Judge Brogdon signed the scheduling order on December 19, 2000, and filed it on January 4, 2001.Â Â  Although Judge Brogdon did not hold a discovery conference or a pre-trial hearing, we find no reversible error.Â  
Initially, we reject Appellantsâ€™ contention that Judge Brogdon was required to hold a hearing on the issuance of the scheduling order.Â  Our review of the above-cited rules of civil procedure reveals that the decision of whether to conduct a hearing is a matter left to the discretion of the trial judge.Â  This interpretation of the rules is supported by analysis of Rule 16 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, a rule that is similar to our state court rule.Â  Rule 16, SCRCP editorâ€™s note (â€œThis Rule 16 is similar to the Federal Ruleâ€ with limited exceptions.).Â  Specifically, secondary authority has stated that a scheduling conference is not mandatory and the issuance of a scheduling order does not require formal communication.Â  See 6A Charles Alan Wright & Arthur R. Miller, Federal Practice and Procedure Â§ 1522.1 (2d ed. Supp. 2005) (analyzing Rule 16, FRCP, and stating, â€œA scheduling conference may be requested by the judge or the parties, but it is not mandatory.Â  Indeed, Rule 16(b) specifically provides that if the request for a conference is not made within 120 days after the action is filed, the scheduling order will be issued without a conference, although after some communication with the parties. Â That communication may be very informal.Â  As explained in the Advisory Committee Note, the scheduling order may be issued after consultation with the parties by telephone or mail, rather than in person.â€).Â  
Furthermore, within the context of this procedure, Appellantsâ€™ counsel was given sufficient time to object to the proposed scheduling order and request a hearing before the order was issued.Â  Nearly two months elapsed between the time the proposed order was submitted and when it was filed.Â  Despite this time period, Appellantsâ€™ counsel admitted at oral argument that he did not respond to the circuit courtâ€™s inquiry regarding the order.Â  
Based on the specific facts of this case, we find Judge Brogdon did not abuse his discretion in issuing the scheduling order without a hearing.Â  Because we conclude Judge Brogdon properly issued the scheduling order, we also agree with his decision declining to set aside the order.Â  Furthermore, we find Judge Baxley properly deferred this decision to Judge Brogdon.Â  See Enoree Baptist Church v. Fletcher, 287 S.C. 602, 604, 340 S.E.2d 546, 547 (1986) (â€œOne circuit court judge does not have the authority to set aside the order of another.â€).
In conjunction, we agree with Judge Baxleyâ€™s decision declining to extend the time for discovery beyond that which was set in the scheduling order.Â  Appellants brought this action against Respondents in April of 1998.Â  The scheduling order, filed on January 4, 2001, gave the parties until February 19, 2001, an additional forty-five days to complete discovery.Â  In view of this extensive time frame for discovery, we cannot discern nor can Appellants explain how they were prejudiced or that a â€œmanifest injusticeâ€ was created by the judgeâ€™s decision to limit the time for discovery given the case had been pending for nearly three years.Â  Accordingly, we find Judge Baxley did not abuse his discretion regarding the rulings on discovery.
II.Â  Batson Motion
Appellants argue the circuit court erred in allowing Respondents to exercise preemptory strikes which excluded all African-American males from the jury in violation of Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986). Â We disagree.
The trial court must conduct a Batson hearing when members of a racial or gender group are struck and the opposing party requests a hearing.Â  State v. Haigler, 334 S.C. 623, 629, 515 S.E.2d 88, 90 (1999).Â  During the hearing, the proponent of the strikes must present racially- neutral explanations. Id.; State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 124, 470 S.E.2d 366, 372 (1996).Â  â€œUnless a discriminatory intent is inherent in the proponentâ€™s explanation, the reason offered will be deemed race-neutral.â€ Payton v. Kearse, 329 S.C. 51, 55, 495 S.E.2d 205, 207 (1998).Â  The burden then shifts to the party challenging the strikes to show the explanations were merely pretextual.Â  Haigler, 334 S.C. at 629, 515 S.E.2d at 91; Adams, 322 S.C. at 124, 470 S.E.2d at 372.Â  Our supreme court has explained:

Pretext generally will be established by showing that similarly situated members of another race were seated on the jury. Under some circumstances, the race-neutral explanation given by the proponent may be so fundamentally implausible that the judge may determine, at the third step of the analysis, that the explanation was mere pretext even without a showing of disparate treatment.

Â Payton, 329 S.C. at 55, 495 S.E.2d at 208.Â  
The opponent of the strike carries the ultimate burden of persuading the trial court the challenged party exercised strikes in a discriminatory manner.Â  Adams, 322 S.C. at 124, 470 S.E.2d at 372.Â  Whether a Batson violation has occurred must be determined by examining the totality of the circumstances, and appellate courts review the trial courtâ€™s ruling with a clearly erroneous standard.Â  State v. Shuler, 344 S.C. 604, 615, 545 S.E.2d 805, 810 (2001).
In this case, Respondents struck three Caucasians and three African-Americans from the jury. Â Appellants challenged two of the strikes pursuant to Batson.Â  The trial judge conducted a Batson hearing.Â  During the hearing, Respondents offered race-neutral reasons for the strikes.Â  Respondents struck one potential juror due to the residential area where he lived.Â  Specifically, Respondents stated the potential juror appeared to live in the same general area as the Appellants and also seemed to be close in age to the Appellants. Â In addition, Respondents noted the potential juror wore an â€œunusual piece of jewelry around his neck.â€ Â Respondents struck the second potential juror because he was a minister. Â Respondentsâ€™ counsel explained: â€œI look at pastors or preachers or reverends very carefully because . . . [they] are inclined to award money maybe under the theory of the milk of human kindness.â€ Â The trial judge found both strikes were proper and found no showing of pretext on either strike.Â  
We agree with the trial judge that the reasons Respondents offered to explain the strikes were facially race-neutral. See State v. Rayfield, 357 S.C. 497, 502, 593 S.E.2d 486, 489 (Ct. App. 2004), cert. granted (Mar. 3, 2005)(recognizing that â€œ[o]ur courts, as well as other jurisdictions, have consistently found a prospective jurorâ€™s demeanor and appearance as nondiscriminatory reasons for exercising a peremptory challenge of the jurorâ€); see also State v. Ford, 334 S.C. 59, 65, 512 S.E.2d 500, 504 (1999) (finding place or type of employment may be race-neutral reason for strike). 
Thus, the burden shifted back to Appellants to prove pretext.Â  Appellants did not show that similarly situated Caucasians were seated on the jury nor did Appellants offer any evidence showing Respondentsâ€™ explanations were fundamentally implausible.Â  Instead, Appellants simply disagreed with the legitimacy of Respondentsâ€™ explanations.Â  Thus, Appellants failed to meet their burden.[6]Â  
III.Â  Exclusion of Witnesses
Appellants argue the trial judge erred in excluding their expert, Dr. Fish, and their witnesses, Dr. Chewning and Dr. Graham, from trial.[7]Â  Appellants contend the court failed to consider the factors set forth in Jumper v. Hawkins, 348 S.C. 142, 558 S.E.2d 911 (Ct. App. 2001), before excluding their witnesses. Â We disagree. 
As a threshold matter, it is undisputed that Appellants failed to specifically name the above-listed witnesses in their answer to Respondentsâ€™ interrogatories within the time limits established by the scheduling order. Â Given Appellants failure to strictly comply with the scheduling order, the trial judge had the discretionary authority to impose the appropriate sanction if any was warranted.Â  Thus, the question becomes whether the judge abused his discretion in excluding Appellantsâ€™ three witnesses.Â  See Laney v. Hefley, 262 S.C. 54, 58, 202 S.E.2d 12, 14 (1974) (applying former Circuit Court Rule 90 governing interrogatories and finding that â€œwhat sanctions, if any, are to be imposed where there is a failure to fully comply with the ruleâ€ is left largely to the discretion of the trial judge); Dunn v. Coca-Cola Bottling Co., 307 S.C. 426, 432, 415 S.E.2d 590, 593 (Ct. App. 1992), revâ€™d on other grounds, 311 S.C. 43, 426 S.E.2d 756 (1993) (stating â€œ[t]he decision of whether or not to allow a witness to testify who was not previously listed on answers to interrogatories rests within the sound discretion of the trial judgeâ€); see also Callen v. Callen, 365 S.C. 618, 627, 620 S.E.2d 59, 64 (2005) (finding family court failed to exercise discretion in ruling on defendantâ€™s motion to exclude plaintiffâ€™s witness where court failed to make appropriate inquiry).
In Jumper, this court specifically addressed the authority of a trial judge to exclude the testimony of an expert witness.Â  We held a trial judge is required to consider and evaluate the following factors prior to excluding a witness:Â  

  
    
      
        (1) 
         the type of witness involved;
      
      
        (2)  
         the content of the evidence emanating from the proffered witness;
      
      
        (3)   
         the nature of the failure or neglect or refusal to furnish the witnessâ€™ name;
      
      
        (4)  
         the degree of surprise to the other party, including the prior knowledge of the name of the witness; and
      
      
        (5)  
         the prejudice to the opposing party.Â 
      
    
  

Jumper, 348 S.C. at 152, 558 S.E.2d at 916. 
Although we recognize that the trial judge excluded the testimony of Dr. Fish, Dr. Chewning, and Dr. Graham without specifically enunciating the Jumper factors, we believe his failure to do so is not sufficient to constitute reversible error.Â  Based on our review of the record, we find the judge considered the requisite factors and made the appropriate inquiry before ultimately excluding the challenged witnesses.Â Â  
Initially, we note Respondentsâ€™ counsel prefaced his argument concerning his motion in limine by directing the judgeâ€™s attention to Jumper.Â  Furthermore, in the course of the extensive discussion on this motion the judge either heard through arguments of counsel or elicited information sufficient to satisfy each Jumper factor.
In terms of Dr. Fish, the judge was aware that Appellants sought to call him as an expert witness.Â  The judge was also apprised of Dr. Fishâ€™s testimony.Â  Appellantsâ€™ counsel explained that he intended to call Dr. Fish in response to the contradictory information the Respondents elicited in their deposition of Appellantsâ€™ initial expert witness.Â  Appellantsâ€™ claimed the testimony of their first expert witness was inconsistent because the witness did not have access to all of Arthurâ€™s medical records.Â  Additionally, as part of their return to Respondentsâ€™ written motion in limine, Appellants submitted an affidavit in which Dr. Fish summarized his expert opinion.
As to the third and fourth Jumper factors, there is evidence that Appellants failed to or neglected to furnish Respondents with the name and information of Dr. Fish until after the discovery deadline.Â  Appellantsâ€™ filed their Complaint on April 30, 1998.Â  They did not list Dr. Fish as an expert witness in their original or supplemental answers to Respondentsâ€™ interrogatories.Â  In a letter to Respondents dated February 16, 2001, Appellants first mentioned enlisting Dr. Fish as an expert witness.Â  In a follow-up letter to Respondents dated March 2, 2001, Appellants identified Dr. Fish as another expert.Â  This letter, however, was beyond the February 19, 2001 deadline set by the scheduling order.Â Â  This delay is inexplicable given Appellantsâ€™ counsel told the judge during the motion in limine hearing that â€œ[t]his witness was set up ever since 1999 on this case.â€ 
This late notification inevitably created significant surprise to Respondents.Â  In a letter dated March 7, 2001, Respondents notified Appellants that they took the position that Dr. Fish was not a named expert because he was not identified before the discovery deadline.Â  After the case was set for date certain on January 14, 2002, Respondentsâ€™ again informed Appellants by letter dated October 23, 2001, of their position regarding Dr. Fish and requested Appellants respond if they were in disagreement. Â Appellants offered no response until the case was called for trial.Â Â  
Finally, given these circumstances, Respondents were prejudiced by the fact that they did not have time to depose Dr. Fish prior to trial given Appellants identified him as a definite witness after the discovery deadline and failed to provide any additional information regarding this out-of-state expert.Â  
As to Dr. Graham and Dr. Chewning, we initially question whether Appellants preserved for our review any argument concerning the exclusion of these witnesses.Â  A review of their brief reveals that Appellants only specifically referenced Dr. Fish by name. Â See First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994) (noting where a party fails to cite authority or where the argument is simply a conclusory statement, the party is deemed to have abandoned the issue).Â  Because, however, the argument was made to the trial judge and the Appellants generally discuss these two witnesses, we have decided to address the issue on the merits.
Similar to the judgeâ€™s decision to exclude Dr. Fish, we also find the judge properly excluded Dr. Graham and Dr. Chewning.Â  With respect to the first and second Jumper factors, Appellants informed the judge that Dr. Graham and Dr. Chewning were treating physicians of Arthur and had access to his medical records. Â Appellants further explained that Dr. Chewning was a â€œsubsequent caretakerâ€ of Arthur and had â€œin essence saved that manâ€™s life.â€Â  However, Appellants informed the judge that neither witness could testify to the events of May 8, 1995, because they were not present when the tooth extraction took place. 
In terms of Appellantsâ€™ failure to furnish Respondents with the names of these witnesses, the record reflects that neither witness was specifically listed in response to Respondentsâ€™ interrogatories. Â Instead, Appellants indicated in their response that they would â€œpermit review of [the following] medical records regarding treatment and costâ€ from Carolina Hospital Systems, Graham Clinic, and Dr. Chewning.Â  
Finally, there is evidence that Respondents were significantly surprised and prejudiced by Appellantsâ€™ decision to call these two witnesses at trial given Respondents did not receive notice that these witnesses had been subpoenaed until the Friday before the trial that was scheduled for Monday.Â  Due to the late notification, Respondents were unable to depose either witness before trial.
Accordingly, we find the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in excluding Appellantsâ€™ three witnesses.Â  In reaching this decision, the judge did not exclude the witnesses solely on the ground of Appellantsâ€™ failure to comply with the time limits of the scheduling order.Â  Instead, the judge made the appropriate inquiry and considered the requisite factors.Â  Cf. Barnette v. Adams Bros. Logging, Inc., 355 S.C. 588, 593, 586 S.E.2d 572, 575 (2003) (reversing decision of trial court to exclude plaintiffsâ€™ witnesses where â€œthe trial court made no specific finding of prejudice to the respondents, other than finding the late disclosure would necessitate further discoveryâ€ and the â€œtrial court advised the parties that there had been no disobedience of any order of the court, and that it had not imposed any sanctionsâ€); Jumper, 348 S.C. at 151, 558 S.E.2d at 916 (reversing trial courtâ€™s decision to exclude plaintiffâ€™s expert witness where the court failed to learn and analyze all of the details and information about the witness and the court relied solely on the limits established by the pre-trial discovery order).
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, we find the circuit court did not err in its rulings regarding the issuance of the scheduling order as well as discovery.Â  Moreover, we find the circuit court did not abuse its discretion in excluding three of Appellantsâ€™ witnesses at trial and did not err in denying Appellantsâ€™ Batson motion. 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Although Appellants were represented by counsel at trial and through oral argument before this court, we note they are now proceeding pro se in this appeal.
[2]Â  Trismus is a spasm of the jaw muscles that makes it difficult to open the mouth. 
[3]Â  The complaint alleged Dr. Eagerton extracted Arthurâ€™s tooth.Â  At trial, however, Arthur testified Dr. Sojourner extracted his tooth.Â  Respondents denied Dr. Eagerton ever treated Arthur. Â Dr. Eagerton is now deceased.Â  He passed away after the trial.
[4]Â  Although Appellants raise three separate issues, we have consolidated the related issues under one heading in the interest of clarity and brevity.
[5]Â  We note that it is questionable whether Respondentsâ€™ counselâ€™s letter combined with the attached proposed scheduling order constituted a motion under Rule 7(b), SCRCP.Â  Rule 7(b) provides that motions â€œshall be made in writing, shall state with particularity the grounds therefor, and shall set forth the relief or order sought.â€Â  Although the letter and proposed order were not necessarily the equivalent of a formal motion, the letter was in writing and it expressed counselâ€™s concerns regarding discovery. Â The attached proposed scheduling order also set forth the relief sought by Respondents. Â In addition, Respondentsâ€™ counsel mailed a copy of the letter and the proposed order to Appellantsâ€™ counsel.Â  Because the circuit court and the parties were aware of the substance of Respondentsâ€™ request, we do not believe Appellants were prejudiced by the absence of a formal motion.Â  Cf. DM Co. v. Nycoil Co., 273 S.C. 496, 499, 257 S.E.2d 499, 500 (1979) (holding judgment by default was precluded where oral response to pleadings, which did not comply with strictures of circuit court rules, at a rule to show cause hearing was sufficient to comply with substantive requirement of the rules given plaintiff had actual notice of both the existence and contents of defendantâ€™s response to plaintiffâ€™s Complaint). 
[6]Â  In their brief, Appellants note they raised a Batson challenge regarding the â€œabnormal excusing [of] a black male juror from the panel after all voir dire and other inquires into the jury selection process had been concluded.â€Â  Appellants, however, failed to provide arguments or supporting authority for this assertion.Â  Thus, the issue is deemed abandoned on appeal. See First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994) (noting where a party fails to cite authority or where the argument is simply a conclusory statement, the party is deemed to have abandoned the issue).
[7]Â  We reject Respondentsâ€™ claim that Appellants failed to preserve this issue for review because Appellants did not proffer the testimony of the witnesses at trial.Â  After the trial judge granted Respondentsâ€™ motion to exclude the witnesses, Appellants asked if they could note for the record that they intended to call the excluded witnesses. Â Judge Baxley replied, â€œSure you may.â€ Â Appellants then noted each witness Appellants would have called if the trial judge had allowed the witnessâ€™ testimony.

text:
Hambrick v. Ditech


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Kristy and Scott Hambrick, and Others Similarly Situated,
Appellants,
v.
GMAC Mortgage Corporation D/B/A Ditech.com, and Milton R. Cooley, an Agent, and John Doe, on behalf of other undiscovered Defendant Agents,
Defendants,
Of Whom GMAC Mortgage Corporation d/b/a ditech. com is
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4104
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed April 17, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Paul H. Hulsey, William J. Cook, of Charleston, for Appellants.
J.J. Van Ginhoven and James Y. Becker, both of Columbia and James W. McGarry, of Boston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, J.:Â  In this civil action, the circuit court dismissed Scott and Kristy Hambrickâ€™s (the Hambricks) suit against GMAC Mortgage Corporation, doing business as ditech.com (Ditech).Â  The circuit court found the Hambricksâ€™s claims against Ditech all stemmed from the allegation that Ditech was engaged in the unauthorized practice of law.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court concluded it lacked jurisdiction to hear this case and granted Ditechâ€™s motion dismissing the suit.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
The Hambricks obtained a real estate loan from Ditech that was secured by their home in Aiken County.Â  The Hambricks claim Ditech engaged in the unauthorized practice of law during the loan process.Â  First, the Hambricks claim Ditech impermissibly prepared loan-related documents without the use of an attorney and, second, Ditech failed to use an attorney to close the loan.Â  Â 
The Hambricks initially brought suit in Hampton County, individually and as a class action, against Ditech and Milton R. Cooley, a notary public of South Carolina, who they allege performed the real estate closing.Â  In their complaint, the Hambricks stated eight legal and equitable claims, including breach of contract, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, fraud, constructive fraud, civil conspiracy, and a claim for accounting.Â  Each allegation stemmed from the Hambricksâ€™s claim that Ditech charged them for legal fees that were not provided nor could be provided due to Ditechâ€™s failure to utilize an attorney.Â  Â 
The case was removed to federal district court and ultimately remanded to state court where the Hambricks re-filed suit in Richland County.Â  On July 26, 2004, Ditech moved for judgment on the pleadings, on the basis that South Carolina does not recognize a private right of action for the unauthorized practice of law.Â  At the motion hearing, the Hambricks conceded that if their action sought to determine whether Ditechâ€™s actions constituted the unauthorized practice of law, then the suit should be brought in the original jurisdiction of the South Carolina Supreme Court.Â  However, the Hambricks asserted Ditechâ€™s actions during the loan transaction process, pursuant to case law, have already been declared by the supreme court to be the unauthorized practice of law.Â  Therefore, they allege the circuit court had jurisdiction to assess Â damages stemming from the improperly charged fees.Â  
The circuit court granted Ditechâ€™s motion for judgment on the pleadings.Â  The circuit court primarily relied on Linder v. Insurance Claims Consultants, Inc., 348 S.C. 477, 560 S.E.2d 612 (2002), in finding Â South Carolina law precludes private citizens from suing for money damages based on an allegation of the unauthorized practice of law.Â  Further, the circuit court found the only claim that could be brought based on an allegation of the unauthorized practice of law is a request for declaratory relief brought in the original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court concluded it lacked jurisdiction to hear this case and granted Ditechâ€™s motion dismissing the suit.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The circuit court may dismiss a claim when the defendant demonstrates the plaintiffâ€™s â€œâ€˜failure to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of actionâ€™ in the pleadings filed with the court.â€ FOC Lawshe Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Intâ€™l Paper Co., 352 S.C. 408, 412, 574 S.E.2d 228, 230 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP).Â  The circuit court â€œmust dispose of a motion for failure to state a cause of action based solely upon the allegations set forth on the face of the complaint.â€ Brown v. Leverette, 291 S.C. 364, 366, 353 S.E.2d 697, 698 (1987) (citation omitted).Â  â€œThe motion cannot be sustained if facts alleged in the complaint and inferences reasonably deducible therefrom would entitle plaintiff to any relief on any theory of the case.â€ Id. â€œAll properly pleaded factual allegations are deemed admitted for the purposes of considering a motion for judgment on the pleadings.â€ FOC Lawshe Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 352 S.C. at 413, 574 S.E.2d at 230.Â  This court applies the same standard of review implemented by the circuit court.Â 
Williams v. Condon, 347 S.C. 227, 233, 553 S.E.2d 496, 500 (Ct. App. 2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The sole issue on appeal is whether the circuit court erred in dismissing the Hambricksâ€™s complaint.Â  For the reasons set out below, we find the Hambricks failed to allege facts sufficient to maintain this action.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the judgment of the circuit court dismissing Hambricksâ€™s complaint. Â 
The South Carolina Supreme Court has the duty to regulate the practice of law in this state and, accordingly, has the authority to define what constitutes the unauthorized practice of law.Â  The South Carolina Constitution provides â€œ[t]he Supreme Court shall have jurisdiction over the admission to the practice of law . . . .â€ Â S.C. Const. art. V.Â  Â§ 4; see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-5-10 (2001) (â€œThe inherent power of the Supreme Court with respect to regulating the practice of law, determining the qualifications for admission to the bar and disciplining, suspending and disbarring attorneys at law is hereby recognized and declared.â€).Â  The supreme court has stated the purpose behind laws prohibiting the unauthorized practice of law is â€œto protect the public from incompetent, unethical, or irresponsible representation.â€Â  Renaissance Enters. Inc. v. Summit Teleservices, Inc., 334 S.C. 649, 652, 515 S.E.2d 257, 258 (1999).Â  
In Linder v. Insurance Claims Consultants, Inc., the Linders suffered property loss from a fire in their home.Â  348 S.C. 477, 483, 560 S.E.2d 612, 616 (2002).Â  While their claim was being adjusted by the insurance company, the Linders hired a public insurance adjusting firm, Insurance Claims Consultants (ICC), to advocate on their behalf and they released the lawyer they had previously hired.Â  Id. at 483-84, 560 S.E.2d at 616.Â  Additionally, the Linders requested their insurance company deal directly with ICC concerning their claim.Â  Id. at 484, 560 S.E.2d at 616.Â  When the Linders failed to pay ICC fees Â required under the contract, ICC brought suit in circuit court.Â  In their answer, the Linders asserted, inter alia, that ICC engaged in the unauthorized practice of law, and thus the contract between the parties was void.Â  The Linders also sought damages in tort.Â  Additionally, the Linders filed a declaratory judgment action in the South Carolina Supreme Court seeking a judicial determination that ICCâ€™s acts constituted the unauthorized practice of law.Â  Id. at 486, 560 S.E.2d at 617.
The supreme court found that public insurance adjusting did not per se constitute the unauthorized practice of law, but that some of ICCâ€™s actions, namely advising the Linders of their rights under the insurance policy, amounted to the unauthorized practice of law.Â  Id. at 493-94, 560 S.E.2d at 621.Â  Most important to the resolution of this case, the supreme court specifically rejected the Lindersâ€™s claim, that â€œonce an act is declared to be the unauthorized practice of law, then the circuit court has jurisdiction toÂ  hear various causes of action, including a tort action for damages.â€Â Â  Id. at 496, 560 S.E.2d at 622.Â  Â In rejecting this theory, the supreme court stated:

In bringing the instant action, the Linders acted in accordance with this Courtâ€™s decision in Unauthorized Practice of Law Rules, where we urged â€œany interested individual who becomes aware of such conduct [which may be the unauthorized practice of law] to bring a declaratory judgment action in this Courtâ€™s original jurisdiction to determine the validity of the conduct.â€Â  Unauthorized Practice of Law Rules, 309 S.C. at 307, 422 S.E.2d at 125.Â  We did not, however, authorize a private right of action.Â  Furthermore, there are statutes which prevent the unauthorized practice of law, and while they state such activity will be deemed a crime, they do not sanction a private cause of action.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 40-5-310-320 (2001).Â  When faced with a similar issue, the Supreme Court of Hawaii found that its criminal statutes prohibiting the unauthorized practice of law, while providing remedies such as declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as criminal sanctions, did not create a private claim for damages.Â  Reliable Collection Agency, Ltd. v. Cole, 59 Haw. 503, 584 P.2d 107 (1978).Â  We adopt that reasoning and hold there is no private right of action in South Carolina for the unauthorized practice of law. 

Id. at 496-97, 560 S.E.2d at 622-23. 
The Hambricks contend that, unlike the situation in Linder, they are not seeking a judicial determination that Ditechâ€™s actions amounted to the unauthorized practice of law.Â  They maintain the actions attributed to Ditech have already been deemed the unauthorized practice of law by prior case law.[2]Â  Even if we assume Ditechâ€™s actions were tantamount to the unauthorized practice of law, Linder explicitly precludes a private right of action.Â  
To get around Linder, the Hambricks argue their eight causes of action alleged in the complaint are somehow distinct from their claim Ditech engaged in the unauthorized practice of law.Â  We disagree.Â  Every allegation in the complaint ultimately stems from the Hambricksâ€™s assertion that Ditech engaged in the unauthorized practice of law during the loan transaction.Â  For example, the Hambricksâ€™s claim for breach of contract accompanied with a fraudulent act alleges Ditech breached the contract by â€œmanipulating the process so that attorneys would not be usedâ€ and Ditech â€œknew that licensed attorneys were legally required to handle all real estate loans in South Carolina.â€Â  Even the Hambricksâ€™s equitable claim for unjust enrichment alleges Ditech charged fees for services that could not have been performed â€œabsent the use of a licensed South Carolina attorney.â€Â  The Hambricksâ€™s allegations in their complaint are intertwined with their claim Ditechâ€™s actions constituted the unauthorized practice of law.Â  Only our supreme court has the constitutional duty to determine what acts constitute the unauthorized practice of law.Â  See Â In re Unauthorized Practice of Rules Proposed by the S.C. Bar, 309 S.C. 304, 305, 422 S.E.2d 123, 124 (1992) (â€œThe Constitution commits to this Court the duty to regulate the practice of law in South Carolinaâ€) (citing S.C. Const. art. V. Â§ 4).
CONCLUSION 
We find the circuit court lacked jurisdiction to determine whether Ditech engaged in the unauthorized practice of the law.Â  Further, we find even if the alleged acts were the unauthorized practice of the law, no private right of action exists under Linder. Â Â Accordingly, the circuit court did not err by dismissing the Hambricksâ€™s complaint.Â  For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
SHORT, WILLIAMS, JJ., CONCUR.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument, pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.  
[2] In Doe v. McMaster, 355 S.C. 306, 312, 585 S.E.2d 773, 776 (2003), the court held â€œwhat constitutes the practice of law turns on the facts of each specific case.â€

title: Legette v. Piggly Wiggly
description: Affirms a grant of summary judgment in this slip and fall case where physical evidence clearly proves the lack of any genuine issue of material fact.
text:
Legette v. Piggly Wiggly


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Linda Legette, Appellant,
v.
Piggly Wiggly, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marion County
James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion 4105
Submitted March 1, 2006 â€“ Filed April 17, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
B. Scott Suggs, of Florence, and Daphne A. Burns, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.Â  
R. Heath Atkinson, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Linda Legette appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of Piggly Wiggly in this slip and fall case.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
Legette went to the Piggly Wiggly grocery store in Marion, South Carolina, on June 19, 2000.Â  As Legette entered the store, it was drizzling rain.Â  While she was inside the store, a period of approximately twenty to twenty-five minutes, the rain increased due to an afternoon thundershower.Â  As she began to exit the store, Legette slipped and fell in some moisture near the storeâ€™s sliding glass doors.Â  Immediately after her fall, Piggly Wiggly employees helped Legette into a chair and took photographs of her injuries and the scene.Â  The storeâ€™s owner and manager, Talbert Blackmon, prepared an incident report for its insurer.Â  Legette was seen at the emergency room, and x-rays were negative for any broken bones.Â  She claims to have injured her knee, elbow, thumb, and back in the fall.Â  Eventually, in April 2001, Legette underwent back surgery to repair a disc
herniation.  
Legette sued Piggly Wiggly, Inc., claiming that the store knew or should have known of the dangerous condition and did nothing to remedy it and that the store failed to provide a safe shopping environment for invitees.Â  The trial court granted Piggly Wigglyâ€™s motion for summary judgment, and Legette appeals. 

    STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œSummary judgment is appropriate when it is clear that there is no genuine issue of material fact and that the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Cafe Assocs. Ltd. v. Gerngross, 305 S.C. 6, 9, 406 S.E.2d 162, 164 (1991).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all the inferences that can be drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Redwend Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Edwards, 354 S.C. 459, 468, 581 S.E.2d 496, 501 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œWhen reviewing the grant of summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same standard applied by the trial court . . . .â€Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 861 (2002). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
In order to establish liability in a â€œslip and fallâ€ case, a plaintiff must show that the defendant either (1) created the defective condition or (2) had knowledge of the dangerous condition and failed to remedy it.Â  Wintersteen v. Food Lion, Inc., 344 S.C. 32, 35, 542 S.E.2d 728, 729 (2001).Â  In the instant case, there is no contention that Piggly Wiggly created the dangerous condition, as Legette argues the floor was slippery from rainwater.Â  Therefore, we are left to consider whether Piggly Wiggly should have known of the dangerous condition and failed to take reasonable steps to remedy it.Â  It is well settled that merchants are not required to continuously inspect their floors for foreign substances.Â  Olson v. Faculty House of Carolina, Inc., 354 S.C. 161, 166, 580 S.E.2d 440, 442 (2003).Â  A merchant owes [customers] only â€œthe duty of exercising ordinary care to keep the premises in reasonably safe condition.â€Â  Milligan v. Winn-Dixie Raleigh, 273 S.C. 118, 120, 254 S.E.2d 798, 799 (1979).Â  
In Young v. Meeting Street Piggly Wiggly, 288 S.C. 508, 512, 343 S.E.2d 636, 638 (Ct. App. 1986), this court concluded that the addition of mats at a storeâ€™s entrance, the periodic mopping of the area, and the placement of at least one warning sign were all reasonable steps taken by the store to protect its customers.Â  Customers, as ordinary, prudent persons, should understand the risks posed by rainy conditions.Â  Id.Â  The court stated:Â  â€œSince it is impossible to keep commercial premises entirely free of tracked-in rain during bad weather, a merchantâ€™s liability may not be based solely on the presence of moisture.â€Â  Id. at 510, 343 S.E.2d at 637-38.Â  
While Blackmon concedes there was moisture on the floor, the record shows that Piggly Wiggly took reasonable precautions to provide safe premises for its customers.Â  Legette testified she did not notice water on the floor prior to her fall.Â  She further testified she did not remember seeing any mats or warning signs at the entry where she fell.Â  However, photographs taken by store employees immediately following Legetteâ€™s fall show large mats and warning signs in the area.Â  Legette testified she did not recall employees bringing mats or warning cones out to the area after she fell or while she was sitting for the photographs.Â  Testimony that contradicts undisputed physical evidence generally lacks probative value.Â  See Patterson v. I.H. Servs., Inc., 295 S.C. 300, 304, 368 S.E.2d 215, 218 (Ct. App. 1988) (citing Lail v. South Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t, 244 S.C. 237, 136 S.E.2d 306 (1964) for the proposition that â€œtestimony relied upon by plaintiff to establish liability was inconsistent with incontrovertible physical facts and therefore lacked probative value.â€).
The incident report completed by Blackmon indicated that warning signs were at the entrances to the store.Â  Furthermore, there was testimony from Blackmon regarding the storeâ€™s inclement weather procedures.Â  This included having employees mop the entry areas as needed and putting out warning signs.Â  According to Blackmon, mats were always in place inside the store at the entryway and were only removed if they became so saturated as to pose a greater danger than the bare floor.Â  Blackmon did not recall the mats being removed on the day of the accident.Â  
Even viewing all the evidence in the record in the light most favorable to Legette, we cannot conclude that summary judgment was inappropriate.Â  Legette testified that she did not see the water before she fell.Â  The inference to be drawn is that the accumulation of water was minimal.Â  Furthermore, Blackmonâ€™s testimony, the incident report, and the photographs all support the conclusion that mats and warning signs were in place at the entrance to the store.Â  The only evidence in the record to refute this is Legetteâ€™s uncertain testimony.[2]Â  Initially, she claimed no mats or cones were at the door.Â  Then, when confronted with the photographs, she could only be certain that she did not remember seeing them; they might have been there or they might not have been there. Â Legette also testified that when she fell, she heard Blackmon shouting at one of his employees saying, â€œwhy didnâ€™t they put out the mats, and why didnâ€™t somebody mop up the water.â€Â  Again, after being confronted with the photographs, Legetteâ€™s testimony changed.Â  She claimed she did not hear Mr. Blackmon say anything about mats.Â  â€œI said he said to mop. . . . No, I didnâ€™t say matsâ€”mats.Â  I said mop.â€Â  In light of Legetteâ€™s vacillating testimony and the other evidence presented, we cannot conclude there was a genuine issue of material fact for the juryâ€™s consideration regarding the storeâ€™s liability.Â  
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  In Felder v. K-Mart Corp., 297 S.C. 446, 377 S.E.2d 332 (1989), the court, declining to overturn the juryâ€™s verdict, concluded there was a jury issue regarding whether or not the store had taken reasonable measures to protect its customers.Â  The plaintiff claimed there were no mats or warning signs at the storeâ€™s entrance and that a child slipped on the floor soon after he had fallen.Â  There is no indication in the courtâ€™s opinion that plaintiff ever wavered from that testimony.Â  The evidence presented on behalf of K-Mart consisted solely of an employeeâ€™s contradictory testimony.

title: Kelley v. Kelley
description: This is an action to recover unpaid alimony awarded in a 1974 divorce decree.  The decree required Henry Kelley to pay alimony to Betty Kelley.  The family court granted Husband's motion to dismiss, finding Wife's claim was barred by laches and equitable estoppel.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Betty Kelley, Appellant,
v.
Henry Kelley, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â John M. Rucker, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4106
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed April 24, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John S. Nichols and Robert M. P. Masella, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
Harvey L. Golden and J. Michael Taylor, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an action to recover unpaid alimony awarded in a 1974 divorce decree.Â  The decree required Henry Kelley (Husband) to pay alimony to Betty Kelley (Wife).Â  The family court granted Husbandâ€™s motion to dismiss, finding Wifeâ€™s claim for â€œpast due alimony and future supportâ€ was barred by laches and equitable estoppel.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
Husband and Wife divorced on July 30, 1974, after fourteen years of marriage.Â  The divorce decree required Husband to pay child support of fifty dollars per week per child and alimony of twenty-five dollars per week.Â  At the time of the divorce, Husband lived in Florida and Wife lived in South Carolina.Â  The court awarded Wife custody of the two children, Chuck and Kevin, who, at the time, were twelve and ten respectively.Â  
Less then a year after the divorce, Wife sent Chuck to live with Husband in Florida because she thought Husband could better control him.Â  Husbandâ€™s counsel wrote a letter dated March 25, 1975, memorializing an agreement that would â€œreduce [Husbandâ€™s] support payments by one-half (1/2) from this time forward and [Husband] will have complete custody and control of Chuck Kelley.â€Â  Former Family Court Judge John A. Mason signed the bottom of this letter.Â Â  
The parties continued under this half-support custody agreement for almost two years, until Chuck went back to live with Wife.Â  By order dated September 23, 1977, the provisions of the original divorce decree were reinstated, and Husband was required to make payments to Wife to resolve a support arrearage of $4,450.Â  This arrangement also did not last long.Â  Less than five months after the 1977 order, Chuck returned to live with Husband in Florida, where he remained permanently.Â  Wife maintained custody of Kevin at that time.
Six months after Chuck returned to Florida to live with Husband, Wifeâ€™s then attorney obtained an ex parte order invoking the automatic arrest provision of the September 1977 order.Â  This order was neither issued with notice to Husbandâ€™s counsel nor was it ever served on Husband.Â  Moreover, Wifeâ€™s current attorney conceded no evidence existed to show the order was served on Husband. 
Less than one month after the ex parte order was signed, Kevin, who was then fifteen, went to Florida to visit Husband and decided to move there permanently as well.Â  Husband claims that at this point, because the two children lived with him, he and Wife orally agreed that he no longer owed her any alimony, and she did not owe him child support.Â  Wife disputes the existence of any such agreement.
On October 5, 2001, Wife instituted a rule to show cause, seeking to hold Husband in contempt for failure to obey the previous orders requiring him to pay alimony.Â  Husband answered and moved to dismiss based upon laches, expiration of the statute of limitations, and estoppel.Â  After a hearing on the merits, the family court denied Wifeâ€™s claim for past due and future alimony on the grounds of laches and estoppel.Â  Wife then moved to alter or amend the judgment which was denied by the trial court.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In an appeal from the family court, we have jurisdiction to find the facts in accordance with our view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  This broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings, and we remain mindful of the fact the family court judge, who saw and heard the parties, is in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981).


LAW/ANALYSIS
Wife contends the family court erred by denying her claim for alimony based on laches.Â  We disagree.[2]  
â€œLaches is neglect for an unreasonable and unexplained length of time, under circumstances affording opportunity for diligence, to do what in law should have been done.â€Â  Hallums v. Hallums, 296 S.C. 195, 198, 371 S.E.2d 525, 527 (1988).Â  The party seeking to establish laches must show (1) delay, (2) that was unreasonable under the circumstances, and (3) prejudice.Â  Brown v. Butler, 347 S.C. 259, 265, 554 S.E.2d 431, 434 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
Whether laches applies in a particular situation is a highly fact-specific inquiry; therefore, the merits of each case must be closely examined.Â  Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 297, 519 S.E.2d 583, 599 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Thus, â€œthe determination of whether laches has been established is largely within the discretion of the trial court.â€Â  Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 215, 603 S.E.2d 598, 602 (Ct. App. 2004).Â Â  Additionally, in order for the defense of laches to be sustained, â€œthe circumstances must have been such as to import that the complainant had abandoned or surrendered the claim or right which he now asserts.â€Â  Byers v. Cherokee County, 237 S.C. 548, 560, 118 S.E.2d 324, 330 (1961).Â  
In this action, the family court found Wifeâ€™s delay was unreasonable.Â  It is undisputed that there has been at least a twenty-four year delay from the original divorce order to the present action.Â  Alimony was awarded to Wife in the 1974 divorce decree, reiterated in the 1977 order, and the present action was not commenced until 2001.Â  Although Wife received an order in 1978 holding Husband in contempt, she admittedly never served Husband or his counsel.Â  Despite seeing Husband at numerous gatherings over the years, including the weddings of both sons, Wife failed to have Husband served with the order.Â  She also failed to write or call Husband to request alimony.Â  
Wife further claims she did not know how to locate Husband and therefore her delay should be excused.Â  However, the record shows Wife has seen her children at least once a year since 1978, and Husband has employed both sons intermittently over the years.Â  Wife testified to having a good relationship with her sons, and she offered no explanation as to why she could not have asked her sons where Husband lived.Â  Additionally, Husband presented evidence he owned property in Florida, his telephone number was listed, and he had an answering service when he traveled outside the state of Florida.Â  Therefore, Wifeâ€™s argument that she could not locate Husband is untenable.Â  Accordingly, we agree with the family courtâ€™s finding that Wife was afforded numerous opportunities to enforce her right to alimony over twenty-four years, and her failure to do so was unreasonable.
We further find Husband was prejudiced by Wifeâ€™s delay in seeking alimony.Â  Husband is sixty-five years old and approaching retirement.Â  He testified his finances have been erratic over the past twenty-four years, and if he had known he had a lingering support obligation, he would have asked the court to terminate or reduce his payments.Â  He is currently on his fourth marriage, and is a diabetic with extremely poor health.Â Â  Wife, however, has maintained the same employment since the divorce and has been able to meet her own needs for the past twenty-four years.Â  Therefore, we agree with the family courtâ€™s finding that Husband would be materially prejudiced by Wife resurrecting an alimony obligation over twenty years old.Â  
Wife also relies on the case of Miles v. Miles, 355 S.C. 511, 586 S.E.2d 136 (Ct. App. 2003), for the proposition that Husband cannot orally modify a court order.Â  Although it is â€œaxiomatic that parties cannot modify a court order,â€ Wifeâ€™s reliance on Miles is misplaced.Â  Id. at 511, 586 S.E.2d at 140.Â  In Miles, a husband brought an action to terminate alimony five years after the divorce based on an oral modification.Â  Id. at 518, 586 S.E.2d at 140.Â  We found the divorce decree specifically incorporated an unambiguous written agreement by the parties that any agreement or court order could not be modified by the parties â€œwithout written consent of husband and wife.â€Â  Id.Â  In this action, no agreement exists regarding modification in the original divorce order as there was in Miles.Â  Moreover, Husband is not seeking oral modification of a court order.Â  Rather he argues that the conduct of both parties over the years reflects their mutual agreement that Husband no longer owed alimony.Â  We find it particularly noteworthy that Wife sought to have Husband held in contempt in 1978, but failed to serve the order on Husband when Chuck and Kevin subsequently moved in with Husband.Â  The reasonable inference from the evidence is Wife agreed not to pursue Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation because Husband had a claim for child support against her.Â Â  Therefore, Wifeâ€™s reliance on Miles is misplaced.Â Â Â  
Wife lastly argues the family court erred in finding her claims barred by equitable estoppel, arguing that Husband did not meet his burden in establishing equitable estoppel.Â  We disagree.Â  
In South Carolina, â€œthe essential elements of estoppel are divided between the estopped party and the party claiming estoppel.â€Â  Provident Life & Accident Ins. Co. v. Driver, 317 S.C. 471, 477, 451 S.E.2d 924, 928 (Ct. App. 1994) (citations omitted).Â  As to the party being estopped, the elements are: 1) conduct which amounts to a false representation, or conduct calculated to convey the impression that the facts are otherwise, 2) the intention that such conduct shall be acted upon by the other party, and 3) knowledge of the true facts.Â  Id. at 477, 451 S.E.2d at 928; Johns v. Johns, 309 S.C. 199, 204, 420 S.E.2d 856, 859 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  In order to claim estoppel, Husband must show: â€œ1) a lack of knowledge and the means of knowledge of truth as to facts in question; 2) justifiable reliance upon the conduct of the party estopped; and 3) prejudicial change in the position of the party claiming estoppel.â€Â  Walton v. Walton, 282 S.C. 165, 168, 318 S.E.2d 14, 16 (1984).Â  
Here, Wifeâ€™s conduct conveyed the impression that Husband was no longer obligated to pay alimony based on Husbandâ€™s understanding that Wife agreed to waive alimony in exchange for him having custody of the children and based on Wifeâ€™s failure to demand alimony from Husband in over twenty years.Â  Further, Wife intended Husband to rely on the agreement that he not pay her alimony, so that he, in turn, would not pursue child support against her.Â  Husbandâ€™s decision not to seek child support also shows he was justified in relying on the partiesâ€™ decision to mutually waive support obligations.Â  Lastly, Husband changed his position in reliance on the agreement because if he had known he had a lingering support obligation, he would have sought to have his obligation reduced or eliminated.Â  Therefore, we find the family court correctly concluded equitable estoppel would also bar Wifeâ€™s claim for alimony.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s finding that Wifeâ€™s claim for past due alimony and future alimony should be barred on the grounds of laches and equitable estoppel is hereby
 AFFIRMED.[3]
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Because alimony is a continuing obligation, the doctrine of laches would not apply to Husbandâ€™s future alimony payments.Â  See Stephens v. Hamrick, 358 S.E.2d 547 (N.C. Ct. App. 1987) (refusing to apply doctrine of laches to the enforcement of a court order for alimony because â€œthe obligation to furnish support is continuous [and therefore] a lapse of time will not be a bar to the commencementâ€).Â  However, the family court found Wifeâ€™s claim for â€œpast due alimony and future supportâ€ was barred by laches and equitable estoppel.Â  We affirm that order, but note that Wifeâ€™s claim for future support is barred solely by the doctrine of equitable estoppel, an issue we discuss below.Â  
[3]Â  Because our resolution of these issues is dispositive, we need not address Appellantâ€™s remaining issues.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County School Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 428 S.E.2d 886 (1993) (holding an appellate court need not address remaining issues when the resolution of a prior issue is dispositive).
