title: State v. Rice
description: In this murder case, appellant contends the trial court committed reversible error by refusing to sever the murder charge from the trafficking in cocaine charge since there was not any legitimate or close nexus between the large amount of cocaine discovered in appellantâ€™s trunk during a traffic stop almost seven weeks after the murder, and the murder itself, and the undue prejudice of evidence of trafficking in cocaine warranted a severance.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Russell W. Rice, Jr., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion 4107
Heard April 6, 2006 â€“ Filed April 24, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Â Russell W. Rice, Jr. appeals his convictions and sentences for murder and trafficking in cocaine arguing the trial court erred in denying his motion to sever the charges.Â  Rice contends he was prejudiced by having a single trial for both charges because the murder occurred six to seven weeks before the cocaine trafficking.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In September or October of 2002, upon leaving a restaurant in Greenville, Rice discovered his car, a 1994 Mercury Topaz, had been stolen from the parking lot.Â  Rice suspected Homer Johnson, an acquaintance who sold drugs, stole the car.Â  Drugs and money were inside the vehicle when it was stolen.
On November 4, 2002, despite Riceâ€™s suspicion that Johnson had stolen his car, Rice and Johnson entered into a drug deal.Â  Johnson possessed twenty pounds of marijuana that he, Rice, and another person, Johnny Hamby, â€œcut upâ€ into twenty individual bags.Â  Johnson gave Rice ten pounds of marijuana and told him he owed $11,000.Â  Although Rice was unhappy that he received only ten pounds of marijuana, he told Johnson he would pay him the money the next day.
The following day, Rice phoned Hamby.Â  He asked Hamby to call Johnson and tell him that Rice would meet him at a Super 8 Motel.Â  Hamby relayed the message to Johnson.Â  Johnson was murdered at the motel.
During the course of the police investigation, Daniel Fuller, the investigator assigned to the case, attempted to contact Rice numerous times by telephone.Â  On December 26, Investigator Fuller spoke with Rice, who informed Fuller he was leaving town and would not return until December 30.Â  Fuller was skeptical of Rice and began looking for Rice in Greenville.Â  Fuller observed Rice driving a 1994 Mercury Topaz â€“ the car Rice claimed Johnson had stolen from him a few months earlier.Â  Fuller found the car at a motel and discovered it was not insured or properly registered in South Carolina.Â  Further, the forty-five day paper tag had expired.Â  Fuller set up surveillance at the exits of the motel.
When Rice left the parking lot, Corporal Dave Dempsey followed Rice and pulled him over.Â  Rice was unable to provide proof of insurance.Â  Dempsey and Fuller asked Rice to exit the vehicle.Â  They patted Rice down to see if he had a weapon.Â  Dempsey found a pistol in Riceâ€™s front pocket and $2,500.Â  They arrested Rice for the traffic violations.Â  The officers conducted an inventory search before they removed the car from the scene.Â  A search of the trunk produced a large amount of cocaine, a scale, and a rifle cut into several pieces in a plastic bag.Â  Rice was subsequently charged with murder and trafficking in cocaine.
Before trial, Rice moved to sever the murder and trafficking in cocaine charges.Â  Rice argued the traffic stop occurred six to seven weeks after the murder and the only connection between the two was that a weapon was found with the cocaine.Â  Therefore, Rice alleged, no nexus between the two charges existed.Â  The State disagreed and claimed the reason for the stop was the murder.Â  The State believed the rifle found in Riceâ€™s car was the murder weapon.Â  The State contended the â€œdrug transaction was at the root of the murder itselfâ€ and the two charges involved the same or similar evidence.Â  The trial court denied the motion to sever the charges.Â  A jury convicted Rice of both charges.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A motion for severance is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  State v. Walker, 366 S.C. 643, 623 S.E.2d 122 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. Simmons, 352 S.C. 342, 573 S.E.2d 856 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  The trial courtâ€™s ruling will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion.Â 
State v. Harris, 351 S.C. 643, 572 S.E.2d 267 (2002); State v. Tucker, 324 S.C. 155, 478 S.E.2d 260 (1996); Walker, 366 S.C. at 656, 623 S.E.2d at 128; see also State v. Grace, 350 S.C. 19, 564 S.E.2d 331 (Ct. App. 2002) (declaring circuit court has wide discretion when deciding whether to consolidate charges for trial and its decision will only be overturned when abuse of discretion has occurred).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when a trial courtâ€™s decision is unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.Â  Walker, 366 S.C. at 656, 623 S.E.2d at 129.
LAW/ANALYSIS
SEVERANCE
Rice contends the trial court erred in refusing to sever the murder and trafficking in cocaine charges.Â  Rice maintains the cocaine discovered in his car was unrelated to the murder that occurred six to seven weeks earlier.Â  Therefore, Rice avers any evidence of cocaine trafficking was prejudicial to Rice in the murder trial, warranting severance of the charges.Â  We disagree.
The appellate court considers several factors when deciding whether the trial courtâ€™s consolidation of charges was proper.Â  Where the offenses charged in separate indictments are of the same general nature involving connected transactions closely related in kind, place and character, the trial judge has the power, in his discretion, to order the indictments tried together if the defendantâ€™s substantive rights would not be prejudiced.Â  State v. Cutro, 365 S.C. 366, 618 S.E.2d 890 (2005);
State v. Smith, 322 S.C. 107, 470 S.E.2d 364 (1996); State v. Simmons, 352 S.C. 342, 573 S.E.2d 856 (Ct. App. 2002); State v. Jones, 325 S.C. 310, 479 S.E.2d 517 (Ct. App. 1996); see also State v. Sullivan, 277 S.C. 35, 282 S.E.2d 838 (1981) (noting where offenses charged in separate indictments are of same general nature, involving connected transactions closely related in kind, place and character, trial judge has authority, in his discretion, to order indictments tried together over objection of defendant absent showing that defendantâ€™s substantive rights were violated); McCrary v. State, 249 S.C. 14, 36, 152 S.E.2d 235, 246 (1967) (stating â€œ[t]he two offenses were of the same general nature, involving connected transactions closely related in time, place and character; and the trial judge had power, in his discretion, to order them tried together over objection by the defendant in the absence of a showing that the latterâ€™s substantive rights would have been thereby prejudiced.â€).Â  Offenses are considered to be of the same general nature where they are interconnected.Â  State v. Grace, 350 S.C. 19, 564 S.E.2d 331 (Ct. App. 2002); Jones, 325 S.C. at 315, 479 S.E.2d at 519.
Conversely, offenses which are of the same nature, but which do not arise out of a single chain of circumstances and are not provable by the same evidence may not properly be tried together.Â  See Simmons, 352 S.C. at 350, 573 S.E.2d at 860; Jones, 325 S.C. at 315, 479 S.E.2d at 519; see also State v. Middleton, 288 S.C. 21, 339 S.E.2d 692 (1986) (holding although prison escapee committed two murders within a few miles of each other and attempted an armed robbery, the trial judge erred in consolidating the charges for one trial where the crimes did not arise out of a single chain of circumstances and they required different evidence); State v. Tate, 286 S.C. 462, 334 S.E.2d 289 (Ct. App. 1985) (finding that joint trial on identical but unrelated forgeries violated defendantâ€™s right to a fair trial).Â  Cf. State v. Woomer, 276 S.C. 258, 277 S.E.2d 696 (1981), overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991) (ruling that consolidation was proper even though crimes occurred over numerous days because conduct arose from a single uninterrupted crime spree); Simmons, 352 S.C. at 351, 573 S.E.2d at 861 (concluding defendantâ€™s separate burglary offenses were properly joined when both arose out of a single chain of events, were of the same nature, and proved by the same evidence).
Charges can be joined in the same indictment and tried together where they (1) arise out of a single chain of circumstances; (2) are proved by the same evidence; (3) are of the same general nature; and (4) no real right of the defendant has been prejudiced.Â 
State v. Harris, 351 S.C. 643, 572 S.E.2d 267 (2002); State v. Tucker, 324 S.C. 155, 478 S.E.2d 260 (1996); see also Simmons, 352 S.C. at 351, 573 S.E.2d at 861 (â€œFurther, joinder of offenses in one trial is proper if the offenses (1) are of the same general nature or character and spring from the same series of transactions, (2) are committed by the same offender, and (3) require the same or similar proof.â€).
In the case sub judice, two separate indictments were issued against Rice.Â  The first was for trafficking in cocaine, the second for murder.Â  The cocaine trafficking charge arose out of a traffic stop the police set up because they suspected Rice of Johnsonâ€™s murder.Â  The police found the gun believed to be the murder weapon in the same search that produced the cocaine that forms the basis of the cocaine trafficking charge.Â  The State surmised Riceâ€™s motive for murdering Johnson was in part to retrieve the cocaine and money Johnson stole from Riceâ€™s car.Â  When the police arrested Rice at the traffic stop, he was found with large amounts of cocaine and money.Â  Moreover, the testimony at trial revealed the relationship between Rice and Johnson was largely based on selling drugs.Â  The Stateâ€™s theory as to the motive for Johnsonâ€™s murder involved the drugs Johnson stole from Rice when he stole Riceâ€™s car as well as the drug-related argument the two recently had involving the marijuana.
Additionally, Rice suffered no prejudice from the joinder of charges because, without the evidence of cocaine trafficking, the jury would not have received an accurate portrayal of the case.Â  The cocaine trafficking evidence was necessary for a full presentation of the case without fragmentation.Â  See State v. Simmons, 352 S.C. 342, 573 S.E.2d 856 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  In State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 470 S.E.2d 366 (1996), our Supreme Court explained:

One of the accepted bases for the admissibility of evidence of other crimes arises when such evidence furnishes part of the context of the crime or is necessary to a full presentation of the case, or is so intimately connected with and explanatory of the crime charged against the defendant and is so much a part of the setting of the case and its environment that its proof is appropriate in order to complete the story of the crime on trial by proving its immediate context or the res gestae or the uncharged offense is so linked together in point of time and circumstances with the crime charged that one cannot be fully shown without proving the other . . . [and is thus] part of the res gestae of the crime charged.Â  And where evidence is admissible to provide this full presentation of the offense, [t]here is no reason to fragmentize the event under inquiry by suppressing parts of the res gestae.

Id. at 122, 470 S.E.2d at 370-71 (internal quotations omitted).
The information regarding the cocaine trafficking was relevant to show the complete, whole, unfragmented story regarding Johnsonâ€™s murder.Â  Therefore, Rice was not prejudiced by consolidating the two charges.
CONCLUSION
We hold the trial court did not abuse its discretion in refusing to sever the murder and trafficking in cocaine charges against Rice.Â  Riceâ€™s arrest for trafficking in cocaine arose out of the murder investigation.Â  Moreover, Rice murdered Johnson because of their history of selling drugs.Â  Accordingly, Riceâ€™s convictions and sentences are
AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE, J., concur.

text:
Middleton v. Johnson


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Kenneth Middleton, Appellant,
v.
Elizabeth Ann Johnson and Eugene Hollington, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â Jack Alan Landis, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4108
Submitted March 1, 2006 â€“ Filed April 24, 2006Â Â 
 Revised June 28, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Daphne A. Burns, of Mt. Pleasant, and Margaret D. Fabri, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Elizabeth Johnson McCants, of Florence, and Eugene Hollington, of Warner-Robbins, GA, no appearance.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: Kenneth Middleton appeals from an order of the family court denying him visitation with Joshua Hollington, a minor child.Â  Although Middleton admits he is not biologically related to Josh, he argues he is entitled to visitation because he served as Joshâ€™s â€œpsychological parentâ€ for ten years and because visitation is in Joshâ€™s best interest.Â  We reverse and remand. 
FACTS
Middleton and Elizabeth Johnson (Mother) had a long-term relationship from 1979 until the early 1990s.Â  At the time they met, Mother had two small daughters: a four-year-old named Chelsea and a one-year-old named Tenille.Â  Middleton also had two daughters; his older daughter, Andrea, was eleven, and his younger daughter, Kenisha, was four.Â  While Mother dated Middleton, she and her children spent Thursdays through Sundays at his home. Middleton, with Motherâ€™s encouragement, developed a strong, parental relationship with both Motherâ€™s daughters.Â  He supported the two girls financially and emotionally, and even though they are now grown, he still considers them his daughters.Â  In fact, when Chelsea married, Middleton escorted her down the aisle despite the fact that her biological father attended the wedding.Â  
By 1992, Mother and Middleton were no longer in a serious relationship; however, they had an intimate encounter in July of that year.Â  Nine months later, on April 7, 1993, Joshua Hollington was born.Â  During Motherâ€™s pregnancy, she told Middleton that Eugene Hollington was the father of her child.Â  However, after Joshâ€™s birth, Mother called Middleton and told him he needed to see Josh, and she sent a photograph to Middleton when Josh was three months old.Â  The implication was that Middleton was Joshâ€™s father because the resemblance between Josh and Middleton was so striking.
Once Middleton saw the photograph and the physical similarity between Josh and himself, he showed the picture to various family members and friends.Â  They all thought, as did Middleton, that Josh and Middleton were biologically related.Â  Subsequently, Middleton went to his doctor to have a blood test performed, and the test did not exclude him as Joshâ€™s biological father.Â  
Beginning when Josh was three months old, Middleton took an active role in Joshâ€™s life.Â  He regularly spent time with Josh and supported him financially.Â  When Josh was approximately one year old, a DNA test revealed Eugene Hollington to be Joshâ€™s biological father.Â  By that time, Middleton testified he was already committed to being Joshâ€™s father, and with Motherâ€™s blessing, Middleton continued to love and take care of Josh as though he were a son.Â  When Josh was three, Mother lived in a home owned by Middleton that was next door to Middletonâ€™s fatherâ€™s house.Â  Middleton checked on his father daily, and nearly every time Middleton was at his fatherâ€™s house, Mother sent Josh over to visit.Â  Often, Middleton would take Josh home to spend the night.Â  
When Josh began preschool, Middleton and Mother shared the costs.Â  Middleton signed Joshâ€™s report cards and picked Josh up from preschool at least three days per week.Â  Essentially, Middleton and Mother had a joint custody arrangement, with Mother caring for Josh Mondays through Wednesdays and Middleton keeping Josh the remainder of the week.
This joint custody arrangement was interrupted briefly when Josh was approximately four years old, and Mother moved in with her boyfriend.Â  At that point, Mother attempted to stop Middleton from seeing Josh because her boyfriend did not like Middletonâ€™s presence in their lives.Â  This was resolved when Middleton offered to pay Joshâ€™s entire daycare expense, at which point, his normal Thursday through Sunday visitation schedule resumed.Â  
When Josh started public school, Middleton, without Mother, took Josh to his first day of kindergarten.Â  Joshâ€™s teachers from second, third, and fourth grades testified that they all believed Middleton was Joshâ€™s biological father.Â  Even on the days when Josh did not spend the night with Middleton, Middleton would drive him to school in the mornings.Â  He also picked up Josh nearly every day after school, and he attended PTA meetings, open houses, field trips, and other school-related activities.Â  The teachers acknowledged Middleton as Joshâ€™s father in front of Mother, and Mother never corrected them.Â  Middleton also enrolled Josh in the Boy Scouts and in a basketball league. Joshâ€™s basketball coach testified that Josh referred to Middleton as â€œmy dad,â€ and Middleton took Josh to every practice and game.Â  
When Josh was in third grade, Mother began to date John McCants.Â  As the couple became more serious, Mother called Middleton and stated McCants did not want Josh at Middletonâ€™s house every weekend.Â  To accommodate her boyfriend, Mother came up with a schedule where she and Middleton rotated days every week.Â  By this point in time, McCants was living with Mother, and eventually the two married.Â  
As part of the rotating schedule, Josh spent Christmas of 2002 with Middleton and New Yearâ€™s Eve with Mother.Â  According to the visitation schedule, Josh was to return to Middletonâ€™s house on January 1, 2003; however,Â  Mother called Middleton that day and explained that she was not going to bring Josh over because he had been acting up, and she had to punish him.Â  When Josh came over the following day, he hugged Middleton and told him that Mother had left marks on him by hitting him with a studded belt.Â  Josh showed Middleton the marks on his upper thighs, near his groin area.Â  
Middleton testified that he had previously observed signs of physical abuse and that he had spoken to Mother about hitting Josh.Â  Middleton was concerned that if he reported this suspected abuse, Mother would forbid him from seeing Josh.Â  Because Middleton did not want to jeopardize his relationship with Josh, he spoke with Joshâ€™s principal about the marks, but did not otherwise contact the authorities.Â  
Later that evening, Mother called and asked to speak with Josh.Â  Â Â Middleton informed her Josh was about to get in the shower, and that Josh would call her back once he was through.Â  Moments later, Mother called back and demanded Josh be brought to her.Â  Middleton did not understand what could have transpired in those few minutes to make Mother so angry, but speculated that Motherâ€™s change in demeanor could have occurred because she thought Middleton might see the marks she left on Josh when Josh undressed to shower.Â  Middleton told Mother it was his night with Josh, and because Josh had been sick earlier, he should not travel outside in the winter right after a shower.Â  Middleton testified he was afraid for Joshâ€™s welfare and refused to bring him to Motherâ€™s house.Â  When the telephone conversation ended, he called the police department and reported the alleged abuse.Â  Mother and McCants also contacted the police to report Middeltonâ€™s refusal to return Josh. 
When the police arrived, they brought Mother and McCants with them.Â  Because Mother had legal custody, Josh was returned to her.Â  Officer Maggie Carver reported the case to the Department of Social Services, but inexplicably, the Department informed Officer Carver in a voicemail that it would not â€œtake the case.â€Â  Officer Carver testified she believed Middletonâ€™s reason for reporting the alleged abuse was out of true concern for Josh.Â  
After this incident in January 2003, Mother terminated all contact between Josh and Middleton.Â  She also contacted school officials and told them Middleton was not allowed to see Josh.Â  Approximately one year later, Mother, McCants, and Josh moved to Florence, South Carolina.Â  
On February 11, 2003, Middleton filed this action seeking custody of Josh.[1]  Â He also filed a motion to have a guardian ad litem appointed to represent Josh.Â  Mother answered, stating the action should be dismissed because Middleton, not being biologically related to Josh, lacked standing to proceed.Â  The family court (1) denied Motherâ€™s motion to dismiss; (2) appointed a guardian to represent Josh; (3)Â  required Middleton to join Eugene Hollington, Joshâ€™s biological father; and (4) denied Middleton any visitation.Â Â  On April 14, 2003, Middleton filed an amended complaint joining Hollington to the action.Â  Despite being joined in the action and having the pleadings served on him by certified mail, return receipt requested, Hollington has never made an appearance or responded.Â  
On June 23, 2003, the guardian filed a motion seeking counseling for Josh.Â  The family court issued an order requiring Mother, Middleton, and Josh to cooperate in counseling.Â  Several months later the guardian filed an ex parte emergency motion seeking to compel Motherâ€™s continued compliance with court mandated counseling because Mother stopped taking Josh to counseling.Â  After a hearing, the family court ordered both Mother and Josh to continue meeting with the therapist, Dr. Kay Newman.Â  
On November 10, 2004, Dr. Newman issued her report recommending Middleton resume visitation with Josh.Â  In her report she stated Josh was a kind, gentle boy whose primary concern was that Dr. Newman understand how much he loves Middleton.Â  According to Dr. Newman, Josh and Middleton separately, â€œreport[ed] a very close, happy relationship between them.Â  Josh reminisce[d] much about Mr. Middletonâ€™s taking him to church, Boy Scouts, signing him up for and attending his basketball league, and other events.â€Â  Dr. Newman noted that Joshâ€™s biological dad had never been involved in Joshâ€™s life,[2] while Middleton had been, with Motherâ€™s blessing, very involved.Â  She also stated McCants declined to be involved in any of the therapy sessions.Â  Further, her report revealed that because Middleton had been instrumental in involving Josh in activities and was an important source of socialization, the move to Florence coupled with losing contact with Middleton, had a negative impact on Josh emotionally.Â  Ultimately, Dr. Newman recommended Josh resume visitation with Middleton, with Motherâ€™s liberal input into the form of visitation.Â  
After a three-day trial, the family court denied Middletonâ€™s right to visitation.Â  The family court found that despite Motherâ€™s position that Middleton had been overindulgent with Josh, Middleton had done nothing â€œwhich would have a negative effect on the relationship between the child and his Mother.â€Â  However, the family court found that under the law of South Carolina, a fit, biological parent has the fundamental right to make decisions concerning whether a third party may visit her child.Â  The family court reasoned that because Josh knew he had a biological father, Middleton could not be his psychological parent, and therefore Middleton had no legal right to petition for visitation.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, this court has the authority to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  This broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981).Â  We remain mindful of the fact the family court judge, who saw and heard the parties, is in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
In this case, we are asked to determine what legal standard applies to a third partyâ€™s claim for visitation of a non-biological child for whom he claims to have functioned as a psychological parent.Â  On appeal Middleton argues he has standing to seek visitation because he functioned as a psychological parent to Josh.Â  For the reasons set forth below, we agree, and find the family court erred in concluding Middleton was not Joshâ€™s psychological parent and erred in finding Middleton was not entitled to visitation.Â  Accordingly, we reverse and remand.Â  
I.Â  Standing
In all child custody cases, the welfare of the child and the childâ€™s best interest is the â€œprimary, paramount and controlling consideration of the court . . . .â€Â  Cook v. Cobb, 271 S.C. 136, 140, 245 S.E.2d 612, 614 (1978) (citing Davenport v. Davenport, 265 S.C. 524, 220 S.E. 2d 228 (1975)).Â  To further promote the goal of safeguarding the best interests of children, the General Assembly has recognized that in certain circumstances, persons who are not a childâ€™s parent or legal guardian may be proper parties to a custody proceeding.Â  Section 20-7-420 (20) of the South Carolina Code grants the family court jurisdiction to award custody of a child to the childâ€™s parent or â€œany other proper person or institution.â€Â  Pursuant to that statute, third parties have been allowed to bring an action for custody of a child.Â  See Kramer v. Kramer, 323 S.C. 212, 473 S.E.2d 846 (Ct. App. 1996) (awarding custody to childâ€™s aunt and uncle over biological mother); Donahue v. Lawrence, 280 S.C. 382, 312 S.E.2d 594 (Ct. App. 1984) (finding stepmother had standing to initiate termination of parental rights action).Â Â Â  
Under the penumbra of custody is the lesser included right to visitation.Â  Because Middleton would have standing to bring an action for custody, it follows that he would also have standing to seek visitation.Â  In Dodge v. Dodge, 332 S.C. 401, 415 505 S.E.2d 344, 351 (Ct. App. 1998), this court found â€œno authorityâ€ to grant visitation rights to a stepfather of nineteen months, once the biological father, who had been in prison, resumed full custody.Â  However, we specifically found no psychological parent relationship existed between stepfather and children, as the children often saw their biological father.Â  Id. at 413, 505 S.E.2d at 350.Â  
In this case, Middleton claims he has a right to visitation based on his status as a psychological parent and the significant harm denying visitation causes Josh.Â  As explained more fully below, we agree, and hold the family court erred in finding Middleton lacked standing to bring this action.
II.Â  Third Partyâ€™s Right To Visitation 
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Psychological Parent Doctrine
In refusing to grant Middleton visitation, the family court specifically found that because Josh knew he had a biological father, Middleton was not Joshâ€™s psychological father.Â  We disagree.
The notion of a psychological parent or de facto parent was first recognized by the South Carolina Supreme Court in Moore v. Moore, 300 S.C. 75, 386 S.E.2d 456 (1989).Â  In Moore, the supreme court found that although a psychological parent-child relationship existed between the child and his unrelated custodians, such a bond was inadequate to support awarding permanent custody to the custodians where the biological parent was fit.Â  Id. at 80-81, 386 S.E.2d at 459.Â  Notably, the supreme court found the psychological parent-child relationship was built largely upon the custodiansâ€™ overt acts, which inhibited the relationship between the biological father and the child. 
Subsequently, in Dodge v. Dodge, 332 S.C. 401, 413, 505 S.E.2d 344, 350 (Ct. App. 1998), this court found that although the children had a close and loving relationship with their stepfather and grandparents, the level of attachment did not rise to the level of a psychological parent-child relationship.Â Â Â Â Â  Therefore, we found the family court erred in granting joint custody to the stepfather and grandparents, and should have awarded the biological father full custody.Â  Id. at 415, 505 S.E.2d at 351.
Both Moore and Dodge recognized the existence of the psychological-parent doctrine; however, neither case explores how a party establishes that he or she is the psychological parent to a child of a fit, legal parent. 
The question of who may be deemed a psychological parent for purposes of receiving parental responsibilities has been answered variously.Â  Some states define a psychological parent by breaking down parenthood to its fundamental elements.Â  In California, for example, a de facto parent is defined as â€œa person who has been found by the court to have assumed, on a day-to-day basis, the role of parent, fulfilling both the childâ€™s physical and psychological needs for care and affection, and who has assumed that role for a substantial period.â€Â  Cal. Rules of Court, R. 1401 (8);Â  see also C.E.W. v. D.E.W., 845 A.2d 1146, 1152 (Me. 2004) (declining to define a de facto parent, but noting â€œit must surely be limited to those adults who have fully and completely undertaken a permanent, unequivocal, committed, and responsible parental role in the childâ€™s lifeâ€).Â  
Other states have attempted to refine the concept further by expanding the definition of psychological parenthood.Â  The Alaska Supreme Court has defined a psychological parent as: 


[O]ne who, on a day-to-day basis, through interaction, companionship, interplay, and mutuality, fulfills the childâ€™s psychological needs for an adult. This adult becomes an essential focus of the childâ€™s life, for he is not only the source of the fulfillment of the childâ€™s physical needs, but also the source of his emotional and psychological needs . . . . The wanted child is one who is loved, valued, appreciated, and viewed as an essential person by the adult who cares for him.Â  . . .Â  This relationship may exist between a child and any adult; it depends not upon the category into which the adult falls â€“ biological, adoptive, foster, or common-law â€“ but upon the quality and mutuality of the interaction. 

Evans v. McTaggart, 88 P.3d 1078, 1082 (Alaska 2004).Â  Similarly, in In re Clifford K., 619 S.E.2d 138 (W.Va. 2005), the West Virginia Supreme Court defined the nature of the relationship that supports a finding that the third party acted as a psychological parent.Â  The court stated:Â Â  

A â€œpsychological parent,â€ who has greater protection under the law in a child custody proceeding than would ordinarily be afforded to one who is not the biological or adoptive parent of the child, is a person who, on a continuing day-to-day basis, through interaction, companionship, interplay, and mutuality, fulfills a childâ€™s psychological and physical needs for a parent and provides for the childâ€™s emotional and financial support.

Id. at 157.Â  
The Wisconsin Supreme Court has developed a four-prong test for determining whether a person has become a psychological parent.Â  In order to demonstrate the existence of a psychological parent-child relationship, the petitioner must show:

(1) that the biological or adoptive parent[s] consented to, and fostered, the petitionerâ€™s formation and establishment of a parent-like relationship with the child; (2) that the petitioner and the child lived together in the same household; (3) that the petitioner assumed obligations of parenthood by taking significant responsibility for the childâ€™s care, education and development, including contributing towards the childâ€™s support, without
expectation of financial compensation; [and] (4) that the petitioner has been in a parental role for a length of time sufficient to have established with the child a bonded, dependent relationshipÂ  parental in nature.


    In re Custody of H.S.H.-K., 533 N.W.2d 419, 435-36 (Wis. 1995).Â  We believe this test provides a good framework for determining whether a psychological parent-child relationship exists.Â  These four factors ensure that a nonparentâ€™s eligibility for psychological parent status will be strictly limited.
The first factor is â€œcritical because it makes the biological or adoptive parent a participant in the creation of the psychological parentâ€™s relationship with the child.â€Â  V.C. v. M.J.B., 748 A.2d 539, 552 (N.J. 2000) (explaining the Wisconsin testâ€™s first prong).Â  This factor recognizes that when a legal parent invites a third party into a childâ€™s life, and that invitation alters a childâ€™s life by essentially providing him with another parent, the legal parentâ€™s rights to unilaterally sever that relationship are necessarily reduced.Â  The legal parentâ€™s active fostering of the psychological parent-child relationship is significant because the legal parent has control over whether or not to invite anyone into the private sphere between parent and child.Â  Where a legal parent encourages a parent-like relationship between a child and a third party, â€œthe right of the legal parent [does] not extend to erasing a relationship between [the third party] and her child which [the legal parent] voluntarily created and actively fostered.â€Â  Id. at 552 (citing J.A.L. v. E.P.H., 682 A.2d 1314, 1322 (Pa. 1996)).Â  A parent has the absolute control and ability to maintain a zone of privacy around his or her child.Â  However, a parent cannot maintain an absolute zone of privacy if he or she voluntarily invites a third party to function as a parent to the child.Â  See In re E.L.M.C., 100 P.3d 546, 560 (Colo. Ct. App. 2004); see also Rubano v. DiCenzo, 759 A.2dÂ  959, 976 (R.I. 2000) (explaining that when a legal parent allows a third-party to assume a role equal to one of the childâ€™s two parents, she renders her own parental rights with respect to the minor child â€œless exclusive and less exclusoryâ€ than they otherwise would have been).Â  
As for the second prong, which considers whether the psychological parent and child have lived together, it further protects the legal parent by restricting the class of third-parties seeking parental rights.Â  Normally, the child, legal parent, and psychological parent have at one point, all resided together under the same roof.Â  However, we can conceive of a situation, as in this case, where the legal parent and the psychological parent operated under a sort of joint custody agreement where the child spends half the time at the legal parentâ€™s house.Â  The other half of the time is spent at the psychological parentâ€™s house, which the child also considers home.Â  This type of arrangement also suffices to meet the second part of the test. 
The last two prongs are the most important because they ensure both that the psychological parent assumed the responsibilities of parenthood and that there exists a parent-child bond between the psychological parent and child. The psychological parent must undertake the obligations of parenthood by being affirmatively involved in the childâ€™s life.Â  The psychological parent must assume caretaking duties and provide emotional support for the child.Â  These duties, however, must be done for reasons other than financial gain, which guarantees that a paid babysitter or nanny cannot qualify for psychological parent status.Â  See In re E.L.M.C., 100 P.3d at 560 (citing Rubano, 759 A.2dÂ  at 976) (â€œThe additional elements further protect the legal parent against claims by neighbors, caretakers, babysitters, nannies, au pairs, nonparental relatives, and family friends.â€).Â  We further note that when both biological parents are involved in the childâ€™s life, a third partyâ€™s relationship with the child could never rise to the level of a psychological parent, as there is no parental void in the childâ€™s life.Â  
Additionally, the length of time the psychological parent acted in a parental capacity must be sufficient for a parent-child bond to have been established.Â  The existence of a parent-child bond â€œis simply not a court-bestowed determination . . . [t]he finding of the existence of such a bond reflects that the singular emotional and spiritual connection, ordinarily only expected in the relationship of a legal parent and child, has been created between an adult and childâ€ who have neither blood nor adoption between them.Â  Id. at 557 (Long, J., concurring).Â  Further, â€œinherent in the bond between child and psychological parent is the risk of emotional harm to the child should the relationship be curtailed or terminated.â€Â  In re E.L.M.C., 100 P.3d at 560.Â  South Carolina has long recognized the importance of the degree of attachment, echoed by other jurisdictions, between a child and a third-party in making a custody determination between a biological parent and the third party.Â  See Moore, 300 S.C. at 80-81, 386 S.E.2d at 459 (considering whether a psychological parent-child relationship exists in order to determine the degree of attachment); see also In re Clifford K., 619 S.E. at 157 (â€œThe resulting relationship between the psychological parent and the child must be of substantial, not temporary, duration and must have begun with the consent and encouragement of the childâ€™s legal parent or guardian.â€).Â  
Turning to the facts here, the record is replete with evidence showing that Mother invited Middleton to act as a father.Â  Mother sent Middleton pictures of Josh as a baby and insinuated that he was Joshâ€™s father. Â When Josh was three years old, Mother and Middleton worked out a schedule whereby Middleton had Josh from Thursday through Sunday every week.Â  Middleton paid at least half of the daycare costs, and was listed as the emergency contact on the daycare registration.Â  Â Â 
As Josh entered elementary school, it was Middleton rather than Mother who accompanied him to his first day of kindergarten, and it was Middleton who brought Josh to school almost every morning.Â  Middleton also picked up Josh from school nearly every day and accompanied Josh on school field trips.Â  Middleton took Josh to doctor and dentist appointments, and Josh attended family reunions and functions with Middleton.Â  Â Â 
For the first ten years of his life, Josh spent a considerable amount of time with Middleton.Â  Mother cultivated this relationship by giving Middleton parental responsibilities and by allowing Josh to spend a significant amount of his childhood with Middleton.Â  In essence, Josh lived with Middleton at least half of the week for most of his life.Â  Mother, by ceding over a large part of her parental responsibilities to Middleton, fostered the parent-child bond between Middleton and Josh.
The second prong in the psychological parent test, that the child and psychological parent reside together, is also met.Â  The evidence shows Josh spent at least half of any given week residing with Middleton.Â  Additionally, Josh had his own room, clothes, and school books in Middletonâ€™s house.Â  
We also find Middleton assumed the obligations of parenthood by taking significant responsibility for Joshâ€™s care, education, and development. Middleton paid for Joshâ€™s preschool.Â  Additionally, he paid mother $250 dollars per month while Josh was in Motherâ€™s custody.Â  Although Middleton had not thought to keep receipts, he was able to document approximately $12,000 he had given Mother over the years.Â  Further, Middleton established a savings account for Joshâ€™s education.Â  
Middleton not only contributed financially to Joshâ€™s development, he also spent quality time with Josh.Â  On weekends they would go to movies and visit Frankieâ€™s Fun Park.Â  On Sundays, Middleton and Josh attended church.Â  Hollington, on the other hand, made no attempt to fulfill Joshâ€™s emotional need for a father.Â  In fact, other than seeing Josh one time when he was three days old, Hollington has never visited Josh.Â  This parental void left by Joshâ€™s biological father coupled with the parental obligations assumed by Middleton compel us to find that Middleton undertook the responsibilities necessary to meet the third prong of the psychological-parent test.
As to the fourth prong, the record reveals Josh spent ten years of his life thinking of Middleton as a father and is suffering greatly in his absence.Â  Dr. Newman, the court-appointed therapist, opined that Middleton is a psychological parent to Josh.Â  She stated that even though Josh has not seen Middleton in two years, he wanted her to tell the court that he misses Middleton and wants to see Middleton.Â  In her clinical opinion, the emotional attachment between Josh and Middleton is so strong that despite the passing of two yearsâ€™ time, Josh still feels a sense of loss.Â  According to Dr. Newman, the severance of the relationship between Middleton and Josh will have a profound, negative impact for the rest of his life.[3]Â  
B. Compelling Circumstances 
In declining to grant Middleton visitation, the family court stated: â€œWhen our law does not allow us to grant autonomous visitation to grandparents against the wishes of a fit parent, I donâ€™t know how we can grant autonomous visitation to an unrelated third party against the wishes of a fit parent.â€Â  While great deference is accorded to the visitation decisions made by a fit parent, the family court can in fact grant visitation to a third-party over a fit parentâ€™s objection when faced with compelling circumstances.
In Troxel v. Granville, the Supreme Court of the United States considered whether the application of the state of Washingtonâ€™s visitation statute violated Granvilleâ€™s due process right to make decisions concerning the custody, care, and control of her children.Â  530 U.S. 57 (2000).Â Â  The dispute in Troxel arose because Granville sought to limit her in-lawsâ€™ visitation to one visit per month and holidays.Â  Id. at 71. In turn, the grandparents sought visitation under a Washington statute that provided â€œany personâ€ could petition for visitation rights at â€œany time.â€Â  Id. at 61.Â  The grandparents did not rely on a common law de facto or psychological parent doctrine.Â  
A plurality of the Court explained that parents have a protected liberty interest in the care, custody, and control of their children.Â  Id. at 65-66.Â  The plurality noted this fundamental right of parents encompasses the presumption that a fit parent will act in the best interest of his or her child.Â  
The Supreme Court held Washingtonâ€™s visitation statute unconstitutionally infringed upon Granvilleâ€™s fundamental right to direct the upbringing of her children.Â  The statuteâ€™s language effectively allowed â€œany third party seeking visitation to subject any decision by a parent concerning visitation of the parentâ€™s children to state-court review,â€ and if the trial judge disagreed with the parentâ€™s determination of the childâ€™s best interest, the judgeâ€™s view would prevail.Â  Id. at 67.Â  The plurality noted the trial courtâ€™s order â€œwas not founded on any special factors that might justify the Stateâ€™s interference with Granvilleâ€™s fundamental right to make decisionsâ€ regarding her children.Â  Id. at 68.Â Â  
The plurality gave three reasons to support its conclusion that no â€œspecial factorsâ€ justified the Stateâ€™s interference in this case.Â  First, the grandparents did not allege that Granville was an unfit parent, and therefore Granville was presumed to have acted in the best interest of her children.Â  Id. at 68.Â  Second, the trial court did not give special weight to Granvilleâ€™s determination of what was in her childrenâ€™s best interest.Â  Id. at 69.Â  Third, Granville had not sought to cut off visitation entirely.Â Â  Notably, the plurality did not consider â€œwhether the Due Process Clause requires all nonparental visitation statutes to include a showing of harm or potential harm to the child as a condition precedent to granting visitation.â€Â  Id. at 73. The Court explained, â€œ[w]e do not, and need not, define today the precise scope of the parental due process right in the visitation context.â€Â  Id.Â  Thus, the Troxel decision, which turned on the constitutionality of the state of Washingtonâ€™s extremely liberal visitation statute, has little bearing on the peculiar facts of the case before us.
We find the decision by our own supreme court in Camburn v. Smith, 355 S.C. 574, 586 S.E.2d 565 (2003), more pertinent to our determination of whether Middleton can be awarded visitation with Josh.Â  In Camburn, maternal grandparents successfully petitioned the family court for visitation of their daughterâ€™s three children over the objection of the childrenâ€™s mother and her husband.[4]Â  Despite uncontested evidence that the children were well-cared for by their mother and her husband, the family court found visitation would be in the childrenâ€™s best interest because their grandparents were a stabilizing factor in their lives. Mother and her husband appealed, and our supreme court reversed.Â  The Camburn court held: â€œBefore visitation may be awarded over a parentâ€™s objection, one of two evidentiary hurdles must be met: the parent must be shown to be unfit by clear and convincing evidence, or there must be evidence of compelling circumstances to overcome the presumption that the parental decision is in the childâ€™s best interest.â€Â  Id. at 579-80, 586 S.E.2d at 568.Â  As an example of a compelling circumstance, the Camburn court specifically mentioned a situation in which denying visitation would cause â€œsignificant harm to the child.â€Â  Id. at 579, 586 S.E.2d at 568.
